title: Gecy v. Bagwell
description: The Court held that votes cast in the wrong precincts must be thrown out, resulting in the declared winner of the election no longer carrying a majority of total votes cast, and ordered a new election.  The Court also found appellantâ€™s notice of protest to be sufficient.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court



  
    
      
Robert Gecy, Respondent,
v.
Tammy Bagwell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26263
Heard December 6, 2006 - Filed February 20, 2007Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Keith D. Munson, ofÂ  Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice, and Timothy Edward Hurley, both of Greenville, for Appellant.
James Theodore Gentry, of Wyche Burgess Freeman & Parham, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Samuel Darryl Harms, of Greenville, for Amicus Curiae Greenville County Republican Party.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Tammy Bagwell, candidate for Simpsonville City Council, contested the results of the municipal election which resulted in respondent, Robert Gecy, being declared winner.Â  The Simpsonville Election Commission (â€œCommissionâ€) invalidated the results and ordered a new election.Â  The circuit court overturned the ruling of the Commission and reinstated Gecy as winner of the Simpsonville City Council seat.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On November 8, 2005, the city of Simpsonville held an election to fill three seats on its city council.Â  The two candidates on the ballot for the Ward IV race were appellant, Tammy Bagwell, and respondent, Robert Gecy.Â  This was an at-large race, meaning all residents of Simpsonville were eligible to vote for the city council representative from Ward IV.
After a hearing to determine the validity of provisional ballots and after a mandatory recount pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-17-280 (1976), the final vote tally was 430-427 in favor of Gecy, with one write-in vote for another individual.Â  The Commission certified the result and declared Gecy the winner of the election.
On November 10, 2005, Bagwell filed a timely protest of the election pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-15-130 (2004).Â  As required by statute, the Commission held a hearing two days later to determine the issues raised by Bagwellâ€™s protest. 
The Commission decided that at least two illegal votes had been cast,[1] and these votes rendered doubtful the result of the election.Â  One of the illegal votes was cast by a voter who moved from her residence in one precinct to a residence in another precinct, and the other illegal vote came from a Simpsonville resident who voted in a precinct where his old business was located.Â  Both voters failed to change their addresses or notify election workers and voted in their old precinct.Â  The two illegal votes were subtracted from Gecyâ€™s total, leaving him with a total of 428 votes, preventing him from garnering a majority of the total votes cast.[2]Â  The Commission then ordered a new election.
Gecy appealed the Commissionâ€™s ruling to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court overturned the Commission and reinstated the popular election result.Â  The circuit court held that in the narrow context of a post-election challenge, the casting of votes in the wrong precinct did not affect the overall tally.Â  The court also found Bagwellâ€™s notice of protest was legally insufficient for failing to state specific facts to apprise Gecy of the basis for the challenge.Â  
Bagwell appeals the order of the circuit court reversing the Commission and seeks a new election for the contested seat.
ISSUES
 1. Did the circuit court err in overturning the Commissionâ€™s ruling that at least two illegal votes were cast, putting the result of the election into doubt and necessitating a new election?
 2. Did the circuit court err in overturning the Commissionâ€™s finding that Bagwellâ€™s protest pleading was legally sufficient?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In municipal election cases, we review the judgment of the circuit court upholding or overturning the decision of a municipal election commission to correct errors of law.Â  The review does not extend to findings of fact unless those findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Taylor v. Town of Atlantic Beach Election Commâ€™n, 363 S.C. 8, 609 S.E.2d 500 (2005).Â  
ANALYSIS
Bagwell argues that the votes cast in the wrong precinct were illegal, and as a result, a new election should have been held.Â  We agree.
In this case, two voters cast a ballot in a precinct where they previously were registered, but they no longer had a valid address in that precinct at the time of the election.Â  Both parties agree that these two votes were not properly cast, and the question becomes whether these illegal votes should be thrown out, which would require a new election.
The election process is exclusively controlled by statute.Â  S.C. Const. Art. II, Â§ 10. Â Â We have recognized that perfect compliance with the election statutes is unlikely, and this Court will not nullify an election based on minor violations of technical requirements. Â George v. Mun. Election Commâ€™n of City of Charleston, 335 S.C. 182, 186, 516 S.E.2d 206, 208 (1999).
As a general rule, statutory provisions are mandatory in two instances: when the statute expressly declares that a particular act is essential to the validity of an election or when enforcement is sought before an election in a direct proceeding. Â George, 335 S.C. at 186, 516 S.E.2d at 208.Â  However, the Court may deem such provisions to be mandatory after an election, and thus non-compliance may nullify the results, when the provisions substantially affect the determination of the results, an essential element of the election, or the fundamental integrity of the election. Â Id. at 187.Â  Where there is a total disregard of the statute, the violation cannot be treated as an irregularity, but it must be held and adjudicated to be cause for declaring the election void and illegal. Â Id.Â  The Court will not sanction practices which circumvent the plain purposes of the law and open the door to fraud. Â May v. Wilson, 199 S.C. 354, 19 S.E.2d 467 (1942).
The use of precincts in our election process is a fundamental part of our statutory scheme.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-5-110 (1976) (â€œNo person shall be allowed to vote at any election unless he shall be registered as herein required.â€) and S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-5-120(A)(3) (Supp. 2005) (providing, as a qualification for registration, that the prospective voter must be a resident of both the county and the precinct in which he intends to vote); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-5-155(a)(3)(iii) (Supp. 2005) (requiring registration board to reject any voter application from which the board cannot determine the proper precinct to be assigned); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-7-940 (Supp. 2005) (voter moving to new precinct must notify the registration board in his new county so that he may be informed of his new, correct precinct); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-5-440 (Supp. 2005) (outlining specific procedures for voting by an elector who has moved to a new precinct but has not notified the county registration board); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-7-920 (1976) (in municipal elections when the councilmen are elected by an at-large vote, the electors shall vote at the voting place in the precinct within which they reside); and S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-13-810 (Supp. 2005) (election protest may be based on evidence of voters who voted in a precinct other than the one in which they are entitled by law to vote).
The disregard of the election statutes requiring electors to be residents of the precincts in which they vote, as well as failing to follow the procedure outlined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-5-440 for those voters who have moved to a new precinct, constitutes more than a mere irregularity or illegality.Â  The precinct system is an essential element of our voting process, and the failure of the two voters to adhere to the statutory requirements for registration and voting requires their votes to be rejected. Â Because the rejection of these two votes results in Gecy no longer carrying a majority of the total votes cast, a new election must be held.
The second issue involves Bagwellâ€™s notice of protest.Â  The circuit court determined Bagwellâ€™s notice of protest to be insufficient and found that her protest should have been dismissed.Â  Bagwell argues that the notice of protest was sufficient under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-15-130 (2004).Â  We agree.
Bagwellâ€™s notice of protest contained eight separate allegations.Â  Bagwell argues that the third ground for the protest adequately alleged the irregularities surrounding the two illegal votes.Â  That allegation asserted, â€œPersons who had not provided accurate information for the voter rolls were nonetheless allowed to cast full ballots.â€ 
Section 5-15-130 requires the notice of protest to include a
â€œconcise statement of the groundsâ€ for the election contest.Â  We have explained that the notice â€œshould briefly state facts or a combination of facts sufficient to apprise the contestee of the cause for which his election is contested, it being insufficient to allege generally the fraud was committed, or to allege mere conclusions of the pleader.â€Â  Butler v. Town of Edgefield, 328 S.C. 238, 245-246, 493 S.E.2d 838, 842 (1997) (quoting 26 Am.Jur.2d Elections Â§ 434 (1996)); see also State ex rel. Davis v. State Bd. of Canvassers, 86 S.C. 451, 458-459, 68 S.E. 676, 679 (1910) (â€œwhileâ€¦technical precision in pleading should not be required [for election contests], still reason and justice require that the grounds relied upon should be stated plainly and clearly that the contestee may prepare to meet them without unnecessary labor or expense.â€) (cited in Butler, supra). 
In our opinion, the circuit court incorrectly determined that Bagwellâ€™s notice of protest failed to meet the statutory requirement.Â  The notice of protest contained a concise statement of the grounds for Bagwellâ€™s challenge as required by Â§ 5-15-130.Â  Unlike Butler, there was no general allegation of fraud, and the notice of protest was sufficient to notify Gecy of the nature of the challenge.
Gecy provides two additional arguments, raised before the lower court but not ruled upon by the circuit judge, that he claims are sufficient to affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  We only address one of Gecyâ€™s arguments.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C., v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (it is within appellate courtâ€™s discretion whether to address any additional sustaining grounds).
Gecy contends that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-13-810, which allows for post-election challenges based on after-discovered evidence, requires the protesting party to exercise due diligence in obtaining information that could have been acquired prior to the election.Â  Gecy argues that because Bagwell could have determined before the election that the two illegal voters no longer lived in the precinct where they were registered, her protest fails because it was not based on after-discovered evidence.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
Although this Court has defined after-discovered evidence
in other contexts, the applicable election statute clearly provides:

A candidate may protest an election in which he is a candidate pursuant to 7-17-30 when the protest is based in whole or in part on evidence discovered after the election. This evidence may include, but is not limited to, after-discovered evidence of voters who have voted in a precinct or for a district office other than the one in which they are entitled by law to vote.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-13-810.[3]Â  In addition, we have previously determined that evidence presented by a challenging candidate that â€œvoters included on the voter registration list were not in fact city residents qualifies as after-discovered evidence under this section.â€Â  Dukes v. Redmond, 357 S.C. 454, 457, 593 S.E.2d 606, 608 (2004).
In this case, evidence of the two voters who cast their ballots in a precinct where they no longer resided qualifies as after-discovered evidence allowed by Â§ 7-13-810.Â  Even though Gecy correctly points out that Bagwell could have discovered the evidence on which she bases her challenge before the election, we decline to require a candidate to review all registration books and match each registered voter with his current address before the election.Â  The amended version of Â§ 7-13-810 and Dukes specifically permit the same type of after-discovered evidence that was used by Bagwell.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision to reinstate Gecy as the winner of the Simpsonville City Council seat.Â  The two illegal votes cannot be counted, and a new election is required.Â  
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The Commission found two specific examples of illegal votes but inferred that other unnamed voters had voted illegally due to the short time available for investigation.Â  The circuit court reversed this ruling, and this issue has not been appealed.Â  
[2] See Broadhurst v. City of Myrtle Beach Election Commâ€™n, 342 S.C. 373, 382, 537 S.E.2d 543, 547 (2000) (â€œIn determining whether an irregularity in the conduct of an election is sufficient to render the result doubtful, the rule deducible from the decisions is that all illegally cast ballots shall be deducted from the total number counted for the declared winning candidateâ€¦â€).Â  
[3] This section was added in 1996 after our decision in Hill v. South Carolina Election Commâ€™n, 304 S.C. 150, 403 S.E.2d 309 (1991); see also Greene v. South Carolina Election Commâ€™n, 314 S.C. 449, 445 S.E.2d 451 (1994). Â In Hill, we held that discrepancies between the district where a voter actually resided and the voterâ€™s district designation on the voter registration list could have been discovered prior to the election and could not be used for a post-election challenge.Â  The amended version of the statute allows for after-discovered evidence that was prohibited by Hill.

description: This is a judicial disciplinary opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands a magistrate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Former Clarendon County Magistrate
Willie L. Bethune, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26264
Submitted January 30, 2007 - Filed February 20, 2007Â 

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Bogan, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
John C. Land, III, of Manning, for respondent. 
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of any sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  After entering into the agreement, respondent resigned his magisterial position.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a public reprimand, the most severe sanction we are able to impose under the circumstances. Â See In the Matter of Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996) (a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office).[1]Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
 Since 1985, respondent was a part-time Clarendon County Magistrate.Â  On October 1, 2006, a female motorist was incarcerated by the Summerton Police Department for traffic and driverâ€™s license offenses.Â  Respondent presided over her bond hearing that evening.Â  
The motorist alleges that, during the bond hearing, respondent asked whether her bra straps were clear or whether the whole bra was clear.Â  She alleges he further commented that they werenâ€™t used to having â€œfine womenâ€ there that often, remarked that her eyes were pretty, and made a remark suggesting that she should show the police officer her navel.Â  The motoristâ€™s allegations are supported by a police officer who was in court.Â  
Initially, respondent reported to ODC that he had no recollection of making the comments.Â  Upon further reflection, however, respondent recalled that the motorist was not wearing an orange jumpsuit like the other prisoners but, instead, a cut-off tank top, which was causing some degree of distraction and/or disruption, so he instructed her to be seated.Â  Respondent reports that any comments he may have made to the motorist were made in that context only.Â  
Respondent reported that, at some point, the motorist asked the police where her car had been towed.Â  Police attempted to telephone the towing company owner for the motorist, but were unable to make contact.Â  The motorist then asked respondent if he could help her to regain possession of her car.Â  Respondent informed ODC that he then made telephone contact with the towing company owner and, at the motoristâ€™s request, arranged to drive to pick up her car.Â Â  
The motorist alleges respondent made sexual advances toward her while they were in the car together and offered to have the charges against her dismissed in exchange for sexual favors.Â  Respondent denies these allegations.Â  Â 
Respondent reports that, while he and the motorist were together in his car, the motorist engaged him in conversation about procedural matters relating to her pending charges and invited him to touch her in a sexual way.Â  Respondent reports he declined the invitation, but did talk with the motorist about court procedure and, in the course of the conversation, revealed to her that another Clarendon County Magistrate, whom respondent named, would preside over her trial.Â  According to respondent, the motorist asked what the other magistrate looked like, whether he was married, and then said she would have sex with this magistrate if he would drop the charges.Â  The motorist gave respondent her telephone number and asked him to relay it and her offer to the other magistrate.Â  Respondent told the motorist he would call the other magistrate.Â  Respondent also gave the motorist his business card from another line of work with his cell phone number hand-written on the back.Â Â  
It is not disputed that respondent telephoned the other magistrate concerning the motorist.Â  Respondent informed ODC that he told the other magistrate â€œa young lady wants to speak to youâ€ and then gave the magistrate the motoristâ€™s telephone number.Â  
The other magistrateâ€™s recollection is that respondent telephoned after 10:00 p.m.Â  After initial pleasantries and general conversation, respondent stated he was calling to see if the magistrate would â€œhelp somebodyâ€ who had traffic tickets pending in Summerton where the magistrate had just become interim municipal judge in addition to his duties as magistrate.Â  The magistrate indicated it was his impression that the motorist respondent wanted to help had some relationship with respondent such as a friend, relative, or possible fellow church member.Â  The magistrate recalled being given the motoristâ€™s name and telephone number and being asked to telephone the motorist.Â Â  Â 
It is not disputed respondent called the motorist at 10:03 p.m. on October 4, 2006, to let her know he had spoken with the other magistrate about the tickets.Â  Respondent left a voice message identifying himself and stating â€œI spoke with [the other magistrate].Â  Heâ€™s gonna give you a call. Â Everything is on.â€¦â€Â Â  When the other magistrate called the motorist, she advised him that she had made a complaint against respondent and they should have no further contact.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent admits he has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should maintain high standards of conduct and should personally observe those standards);
Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 2B (judge shall not allow family, social, political or other relationships to influence the judge's judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall perform the duties of judicial office impartially and diligently); Canon 3(B)(4) (judge shall be dignified and courteous to litigants); Canon 4 (judge shall conduct extra-judicial activities to minimize risk of conflict with judicial obligations); and Canon 4(A) (judge shall conduct extra-judicial activities so they do not cast reasonable doubt on judgeâ€™s capacity to act impartially as judge).Â  Respondent further admits his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the judgeâ€™s Oath of Office), of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â 
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.[2]Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  Further, we hereby prohibit and enjoin respondent from holding any judicial office within the unified judicial system in South Carolina.Â  
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
 TOAL, C.J.,Â  MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondentâ€™s request for oral argument is denied.Â  
[2] As previously noted, a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office.Â  See In re Gravely, supra.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Will Roger Helton, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26265
January 23, 2007 - Filed February 20, 2007Â

Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Desa Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to an indefinite sanction from the practice of law.Â  We accept the agreement and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent was admitted to the practice of law in South Carolina in 1995.Â  From sometime in 2002 through approximately May 2005, respondent employed several non-lawyer assistants who engaged in the preparation for and closing of residential real estate transactions.Â  It is estimated that respondent and/or his firm closed on average approximately 15 to 20 real estate transactions per month with the number of closings increasing over the period of time.Â  
ODC conducted a review of 125 sample files closed by respondentâ€™s firm for a seven month period towards the end of the above-referenced period of time.Â  As a result of that review, ODC concluded that, of the 125 files, approximately 112 were closed by non-lawyer assistants, twelve were closed by respondent, and one was closed by another lawyer.Â  
During the seven month period, respondent personally handled those real estate closings which took place outside of his law office and his non-lawyer assistants (with a possible few minor exceptions) handled the closings which took place in the law office without the presence, assistance, or supervision of respondent or any other licensed attorney (with a possible few minor exceptions).Â  The closings by the non-lawyer assistants were handled without any meaningful supervision by respondent or any other attorney licensed in this state with the non-lawyer assistants preparing the legal documents (deeds, mortgages, and HUD-1 Settlement Statements) and the title insurance commitments and policies.Â  During the seven month period neither respondent nor any other licensed attorney reviewed the closing documents or title abstracts prior to, at, or subsequent to the closing of the transactions and no licensed lawyer was present at the closings.Â  After the closings, the non-lawyer assistants would disburse the proceeds and record the documents without supervision of respondent or any licensed attorney.Â  In most all of the cases, the non-lawyer assistants would sign respondentâ€™s name with his knowledge and consent as a witness on deeds, mortgages and other closing documents, as settlement agent on the HUD-1 Settlement Statements, and as agent for the title insurance company on commitments, final title insurance policies, and other title insurance documents.Â  In most cases, respondent had not witnessed the execution of the documents and was out of the office during the executions.Â  
From 2002 through May 2005, after conducting the closings outside of his law office, respondent most often, but not always, brought the executed documents back to his office and had an assistant witness the deeds, mortgages, and other closing documents even though the assistant had not been present during the documentâ€™s execution.Â  Thereafter, with respondentâ€™s knowledge and consent, a notary public employed by respondent notarized the documents signed by the â€œwitnessâ€ even though the â€œwitnessâ€ had not been present when the documents were executed.Â  
Around July 2005, respondent began the process of winding down his law practice and he ceased conducting real estate transactions.Â  Respondent acknowledges that the winding down of his practice resulted in communication problems and delays in closing files, especially those related to the complainantâ€™s company.Â  ODC believes these issues have been or are being resolved with assistance from the staff of respondentâ€™s former title insurance company.Â  Respondent has now closed his law office and is not actively engaged in the practice of law. 
Respondent represents that his real estate practice grew steadily and substantially between 2002 through May 2005.Â  During this period, respondent moved his law office.Â  Due to unexpected difficulties with the move, the efficiency of his practice was greatly disrupted.Â  The move, along with increasing demands on respondentâ€™s schedule, required respondent to attend to non-real estate aspects of his practice and to conduct an increasing number of closings outside his law office, thereby causing respondent to increasingly rely on his non-lawyer assistants to handle the real estate closings conducted at his office as described above. Â Respondent asserts that the number of closings handled contrary to prescribed procedures were the greatest towards the end of his practice.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of matter); Rule 4.1(a) (in representing a client, lawyer shall not make false statement of material fact to a third person);Â  Â Â Â Â Â Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure non-lawyerâ€™s conduct is compatible with professional obligations of lawyer); Rule 5.5 (lawyer shall not assist another in the unauthorized practice of law);
Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice).
Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this
jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(6) (lawyer shall not violate the oath of office taken upon admission).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall surrender his certificate of admission to practice law in this state to the Clerk of Court and shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30,
RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
 INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

Submitted January 23, 2007 - Filed February 20, 2007Â

FACTS
Respondent represented Complainantâ€™s husband in connection with injuries he sustained in an automobile collision in 2000.Â  In 2004, respondent received a settlement of the policy limits available to Complainantâ€™s husband and a $2,000,000 confession of judgment against the at-fault party.Â  Complainantâ€™s husband died shortly after the settlement funds were disbursed.Â

CONCLUSION

title: Grant v. Grant Textiles
description: This workers' compensation case involves the issue of whether the Court of Appeals erred by finding claimant's accident did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Charles Christopher Grant, Claimant, Petitioner,
v.
Grant Textiles, Employer and US Fire Insurance Company, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26267
Heard November 14, 2006 - Filed February 20, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
Richard H. Rhodes, and Ray E. Thompson, Jr., both of Burts, Turner, Rhodes & Thompson, of Spartanburg, for petitioner.
Stephen L. Brown, Jeffrey J. Wiseman, and Robert P. Gruber, all of Young Clement Rivers, LLP, of Charleston, for respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Petitioner (Claimant) was injured in an accident while walking along a highway.Â  The single commissioner found Claimantâ€™s injury was compensable because it arose out of and in the course of his employment.Â  The full commission reversed.Â  The circuit court then reversed the full commission.Â  In a 2-1 decision, the Court of Appeals reversed the circuit court and reinstated the full commissionâ€™s decision to deny compensation.Â  Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 603 S.E.2d 858 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Claimant was vice-president and in charge of sales at Grant Textiles, a family-owned business.Â  Grant Textiles sold machinery parts and equipment to textile mills.Â  In December 2000, after making a delivery in Greenwood, Claimant traveled in a company-owned pick-up truck to Clinton to meet his father, the CEO of Grant Textiles.Â  He and his father planned to meet customers who were interested in purchasing textile bobbins.Â  Claimant intended to drop off bobbin samples, return to his office, and then go to his home in Cowpens.Â  He was meeting his father and the customers at the Clinton House and Meeting Plantation, which was described as a corporate hunting preserve.Â  Claimant individually owned the Clinton House.Â  Grant Textiles had a corporate membership and often entertained clients there.
Around 5:30 p.m., Claimant neared the entrance of the Clinton House when he had to swerve onto the shoulder of Highway 56 in order to avoid hitting an object, apparently an animal, which was lying on the highway.Â  Claimant turned into the entrance driveway of the Clinton House where he stopped his car, but left it running.Â  He was met on the driveway by the day-to-day operator of the Clinton House, Randy Bickley.Â  Bickley argued with Claimant for a few minutes and tried to assure Claimant he would take care of the debris in the roadway because Claimant needed to meet his father.Â  However, Claimant insisted on helping remove the debris.
Claimant and Bickley proceeded down the highway toward the debris when a pick-up truck crossed into the left lane of traffic to pass another car and struck Claimant who was walking in the shoulder of the highway.Â  Claimant was injured on his right side and had to have extensive surgery on his right arm.
Claimant testified he wanted to remove the debris because it was a hazard to anyone traveling on the highway, to his customers who would be arriving at Clinton House that evening, to himself, and to his father.Â  Claimant testified that removing road debris was not part of his regular job duties, but he maintained he did not have a defined set of duties.Â  He conceded that Grant Textiles had no obligation to remove debris from the roadway in front of the Clinton House and that his only purpose for going to the Clinton House that night was to deliver bobbin samples to a customer.
The single commissioner found the injury compensable because Claimant was injured during his regular work hours while on his way to meet customers in a company-owned truck.Â  Further, the commissioner found that Claimant wanted to remove the debris because he was concerned with the safety of his co-worker father, his potential customers, and the public at-large.Â  Finally, the commissioner found Claimantâ€™s attempt to remove the debris was not a substantial deviation from his employment.
The full commission reversed and stated these findings of fact: (1) the accident did not arise out of Claimantâ€™s employment because the causative element of his accident had no connection with his employment; and (2) that Claimantâ€™s job duties were in no way related to road maintenance.Â  In making its legal conclusion, the full commission determined Claimantâ€™s accident did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.Â  The circuit court reversed and determined there was no dispute regarding the facts in this case and that the full commission erred in its application of the law.
The Court of Appeals disagreed and reinstated the full commissionâ€™s order denying compensation.Â  The court noted that, as the sole finder of fact, the full commission found that Claimantâ€™s
injuries did not arise out of his employment with Grant Textiles because the cause of the accident had no relation to his employment duties.Â  The court concluded that the claim is not compensable because the factual findings made by the full commission are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Chief Judge Hearn dissented and stated that, because there were no material facts in dispute, the question of whether the accident is compensable is a question of law.Â  Judge Hearn stated she would have found that Claimantâ€™s injury arose out of and in the course of his employment.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err by finding Claimantâ€™s accident did not arise out of and in the course of his employment?

DISCUSSION
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  Although we may not substitute our judgment for that of the full commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, we may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 610 S.E.2d 488 (2005).Â  Review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Id.
To be compensable, an injury by accident must be one â€œarising out of and in the course of employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  The two parts of the phrase â€œarising out of and in the course of employmentâ€ are not synonymous.Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 508 S.E.2d 21 (1998).Â  Both parts must exist simultaneously before any court will allow recovery.Â  Id.Â  â€œArising out ofâ€ refers to the injuryâ€™s origin and cause, whereas â€œin the course ofâ€ refers to the injuryâ€™s time, place, and circumstances.Â  Id.Â  For an injury to â€œarise out ofâ€ employment, the injury must be proximately caused by the employment.Â  Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex Div., 245 S.C. 265, 140 S.E.2d 173 (1965). Â The injury arises out of employment when there is a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury. Id.
There are circumstances when injuries arising out of acts outside the scope of an employeeâ€™s regular duties may be compensable.Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., supra.Â  These circumstances have been applied to:Â  (1) acts benefiting co-employees; (2) acts benefiting customers or
strangers; (3) acts benefiting the claimant; and (4) acts benefiting the employer privately.Â  Id. Â An act outside an employeeâ€™s regular duties which is undertaken in good faith to advance the employerâ€™s interest, whether or not the employeeâ€™s own assigned work is thereby furthered, is within the course of employment.Â  Howell v. Kash & Karry, 264 S.C. 298, 214 S.E.2d 821 (1975) (grocery store employee who was injured while chasing two purse-snatchers was found to have suffered a compensable injury).
There were no disputed material facts in this case.Â  Where there are no disputed facts, the question of whether an accident is compensable is a question of law.Â  Douglas v. Spartan Mills, supra.Â  The full commission erred by finding that the accident did not have a causal connection with Claimantâ€™s employment.Â  The accident would not have happened but for Claimantâ€™s business trip to the Clinton House to meet his employerâ€™s customers.Â  Because removing road hazards was not part of Claimantâ€™s job duties, he could have ignored the hazard in the road; however, he chose to remove the hazard to benefit himself, his co-worker father, and his customers.Â  As found in Howell, Claimantâ€™s act, while outside his regular duties, was undertaken in good faith to advance his employerâ€™s interest and, therefore, was within the course of his employment.Â  Therefore, the full commissionâ€™s conclusion that the accident did not arise out of and in the course of Claimantâ€™s employment is incorrect.
The majority opinion of the Court of Appeals upheld the full commission solely on the basis that the factual findings made by the full commission were supported by substantial evidence.Â  However, as noted above, the appellate court may reverse the full commission when the decision is affected by an error of law as it was here.Â  While the appellate courts are required to be deferential to the full commission regarding questions of fact, this deference does not prevent the courts from overturning the full commissionâ€™s decision when it is legally incorrect as it is here.
Furthermore, in this instance, we also reverse the full commission for its issuance of a conclusory order.Â  The Administrative Procedures Act (APA) sets out the requirements for a final order in an agency adjudication of a contested case as follows:

. . . A final decision shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law, separately stated.Â  Findings of fact, if set forth in statutory language, shall be accompanied by a concise and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings.Â  . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (2005) (emphasis added).
In Able Communications, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 409, 351 S.E.2d 151 (1986), we held that an order by the public service commission stating that a telephone carrierâ€™s services were â€œfair and reasonable,â€ with no other findings of fact, violated Â§ 1-23-350.Â  We alluded to the purpose of Â§ 1-23-350, stating, â€œIt is impossible for an appellate court to review the order for error, since the reasons underlying the decision are left to speculation.â€Â  Id. at 411, 351 S.E.2d at 152.Â  We vacated the public service commissionâ€™s order and remanded the matter to the public service commission for compliance with Â§ 1-23-350.
The logic of Able Communications applies with equal force in the instant case.Â  Specifically, in its reversal of the single commissionerâ€™s decision, the full commissionâ€™s findings of fact stated that (1) the accident â€œdid not arise out of [Claimantâ€™s] employment . . . because the causative element of the Claimantâ€™s accident had no causal connection with his employment at Grant Textiles,â€ and (2) â€œClaimantâ€™s ordinary job duties at Grant Textiles did not require him to remove debris from the roads, and the discharge of his job duties and responsibilities were in no way related to road maintenance skills.â€Â  Because the full commissionâ€™s order was founded on the statutory language of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, the APA required the full commission to clearly set forth the underlying facts upon which it relied to support its conclusion.Â  See Â§ 1-23-350.Â  By simply repeating the statuteâ€™s language, with little else, the full commissionâ€™s decision failed to comply with this requirement.
Because the full commissionâ€™s order did not meet the requirements of Â§ 1-23-350 and because the full commissionâ€™s order contained an error of law, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Marion Alexander Lindsey, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26268
Heard January 17, 2007 - Filed February 20, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek and Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, both of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia; and Karen Michelle Quimby, of The Brannon Law Firm, of Spartanburg, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant killed his estranged wife, Ruby Nell Lindsey (Victim), on September 18, 2002, in the parking lot of the Inman City Police Department.Â  The jury found a statutory aggravator pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-(C)(a)(3) (2003) and appellant was sentenced to death.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
 Celeste Nesbitt, a close friend of Victim, was the Stateâ€™s witness-in-chief.Â  On the day of the murder, Celeste gave Victim a ride home from work at about 8:00 p.m. Â In the car were Celesteâ€™s two young daughters, four-year-old Keysha and ten-year-old Kiera, who were in the back seat with Victimâ€”Keysha in a car seat behind the front passenger seat, Kiera in the middle, and Victim behind the driverâ€™s seat.Â  Celeste was driving and Celesteâ€™s mother was in the front passenger seat.Â  The car was a Mercury sedan with dark tinted rear windows.
 Victim was separated from appellant at the time and was staying with her mother.Â  As they neared Victimâ€™s motherâ€™s house, they saw appellant in his girlfriendâ€™s car.Â  Celeste pulled into the yard and turned the car around so appellant was facing them in a head-on direction.Â  Celeste rolled down her window and greeted him.Â  Appellant asked her if she had seen Victim.Â  Because Celeste knew appellant had threatened to kill Victim, she lied and Â answered that she had not seen her in three days.Â  
 Celesteâ€™s youngest daughter, Keysha, leaned forward in her car seat and greeted appellant.Â  Appellant then asked who else was in the back seat. Â Celeste told him Kiera, her older daughter, was lying on the back seat asleep.Â  Because the windows were tinted, appellant asked Celeste to roll down the window so he could see.Â  Celeste answered that the window was broken.Â  When appellant said he would get out to look, Celeste sped off.Â  
 Celeste drove to the police department without stopping while Victim dialed 911.Â  When they arrived, Celeste jumped out of the car and urged Victim to get out.Â  Victim was still in the back seat when appellant pulled into the parking lot and ran toward the back of Celesteâ€™s car.Â  Celeste saw him pull out a gun and shoot into the car through the rear windshield.Â  She dove for cover as she heard additional shots.Â  
 Officer Godfrey was in the police department parking lot when the dispatcher informed him there was a â€œrolling domestic,â€ meaning a domestic dispute involving a vehicle.Â  He saw the two cars pull into the parking lot, and saw appellant jump out and fire two rounds into Celesteâ€™s car.Â  Officer Godfrey took cover and saw two more flashes from a gun.Â  Appellant came around the front of the car and pointed his gun at Officer Godfrey who then fired four rounds at appellant.Â  Appellant was wounded and fell to the ground.Â  
 Victim died at the scene.Â  Four bullets from appellantâ€™s gun were recovered:Â  three from Victimâ€™s head and one from the trunk of Celesteâ€™s car.[1]Â  The bullet recovered from the trunk had traveled through the back seat of the car into the trunk.Â  The car had two bullet holes in the rear driverâ€™s side window and two in the rear windshield.Â  
 Other evidence indicated that during their marriage, appellant struck Victim several times in front of witnesses.Â  In December 2001, he beat her in a restaurant parking lot and left the scene before the responding officer could arrest him.Â  On September 17, 2002, the night before the murder, appellant was arrested on a warrant for criminal domestic violence arising from this incident.Â  He was released on a $1,000 bond; one of the conditions of bond was that he have no contact with Victim.Â  
ISSUES

1.     Was Juror K improperly disqualified?
2.     Should the trial judge have dismissed Juror M for misconduct during the juryâ€™s view of the car?
3.     Should a directed verdict have been granted on the aggravating circumstance?
4.     Is the death sentence in this case disproportional to other death penalty cases?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Juror disqualification
Appellant claims the trial judge erred in excusing Juror K who was disqualified because of his views regarding the death penalty. 
During initial questioning by the court, Juror K was asked if he could impose the death penalty.Â  He answered, â€œI donâ€™t know.Â  I really donâ€™t know if I could or not.â€Â  During subsequent voir dire by defense counsel, the juror gave the following responses.

  
    
      Q: 
       . . . . There are going to be some allegations of domestic abuse in this case.Â  Would that affect your ability to give either side a fair trial?
        
      
    
    
      A:  
       No, sir.
        
      
    
    
      Q:   
       Would that affect your ability - in the penalty phase, would that influence your decision as to whether or not life or death would be appropriate?
        
      
    
    
      A:  
      I donâ€™t know, sir.
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
       In other words, and I donâ€™t want to put words in your mouth, but as I understand what you are saying is you will be able to listen to both sides in the penalty phase and render what you feel to be the most appropriate penalty whether it be life or whether it be death?
        
      
    
    
      A:   
       Right.
        
      
    
    
      Q:  
       You will be able if you felt death was appropriate, you would be able to impose the death penalty?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       Yes.
    
  

Upon questioning by the solicitor, however, Juror K equivocated.

  
    
      Q:
       . . . . I noticed in your questions to (sic) the Judge, you were hesitant about the death penalty.Â  You just did not know about it?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       Right.
        
      
    
    
      Q:
       You know life without parole is an option.Â  He would never get out if he gets life without parole.Â  With death being an option to you, would you ever give death in a case?
        
      
    
    
      A:
       Most of the time I feel it is a better punishment to be in prison for life.Â  I believe that death is not as big of a punishment as going to prison for life and having to stay in prison for the rest of your life.
        
      
    
    
      Q:
       You feel life without parole would be a better sentence?
        
      
    
    
      A:  
       Yes, for something that is - I believe that is worse than the death penalty.
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
       So that would be the better option to you between the two?
        
      
    
    
      A:
       Yeah.
        
      
    
    
      Q:    
       Would that be the option you would give the most cases or all cases?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       I am not positive.Â  I donâ€™t know for sure.
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
       You donâ€™t know what you would do?
        
      
    
    
      A:   
       Right, exactly.
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
       Your belief is that life without parole is a more serious punishment than the death penalty?
        
      
    
    
      A:   
       Yes.
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
      That would be the option you would choose?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       Not necessarily but most likely.
        
      
    
    
      Q:   
       Most likely you would do that?
        
      
    
    
      A:    
       Yes.
        
      
    
    
      Q:   
       So substantially that will be your view concerning the case no matter what the facts would be, that would be your view?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       Yes.
    
  

 Defense counsel then re-examined the juror.

  
    
      Q:
       . . . just so that everybody understands.Â  You feel when given the choice between which would be worse, life in prison without parole or death, you feel that life is a worse punishment?
        
      
    
    
      Q:  
       I believe so, yes.
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       However, just so that I understand, if you felt death was appropriate in a case, you could give it?
        
      
    
    
      Q: 
       Yes, I could.
    
  

The solicitor then followed up with one last question:

  
    
      Q:
       If I understood when we were talking or whatever, you wouldnâ€™t basically look at the facts of the case, you would look at life without parole being the worse punishment of the two based on your beliefs, is that right, sir?
        
      
    
    
      A: 
       Yes.
    
  

 The trial judge found that the belief that life in prison was worse than death would substantially impair the jurorâ€™s ability to follow the law as instructed.Â  He further noted that when asked about giving the death penalty, Juror K â€œtook a very big deep [breath] and exhaled as if he were very uncertain as to whether or not he could do that.â€Â  The judge concluded â€œfrom watching himâ€ and considering his inconsistent responses, that Juror K should be excused.
 A prospective juror may be excluded for cause when his or her views on capital punishment would prevent or substantially impair the performance of his duties as a juror in accordance with his instructions and his oath.Â  State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883 (2005) (citing Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. 412, 424 (1985)); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 135, 607 S.E.2d 57 (2004); State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(E) (2003) (juror may not be excused in a death penalty case unless his beliefs or attitudes against capital punishment would render him unable to return a verdict according to law). Â When reviewing the trial courtâ€™s qualification or disqualification of prospective jurors, the responses of the challenged juror must be examined in light of the entire voir dire.Â  Sapp, supra.Â  The determination whether a juror is qualified to serve in a capital case is within the sole discretion of the trial judge and is not reversible on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Id.Â  A jurorâ€™s disqualification will not be disturbed on appeal if there is a reasonable basis from which the trial court could have concluded that the juror would not have been able to faithfully discharge his responsibilities as a juror under the law.Â  Id.; State v. Green, 301 S.C. 347, 392 S.E.2d 157 (1990).Â  Deference must be paid to the trial court who sees and hears the juror.Â  Wainwright, supra. 
Juror Kâ€™s equivocal views regarding the death penalty, his responses favoring a life sentence despite the facts of the case, and his noted hesitation when asked if he could vote for death, are a reasonable basis for the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion that Juror Kâ€™s views would substantially impair his ability to act as an impartial juror.Â  Considering the voir dire as a whole, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in excusing this juror.
2.Â  Jury view
During the sentencing phase, over appellantâ€™s objection, the trial judge granted the Stateâ€™s request for a jury view of Celesteâ€™s car.[2]Â  After the viewing, defense counsel stated an objection that he saw Juror M

using his arm as a dowel or a measurement.Â  He measured both the front driverâ€™s seat and the back seat of the automobile Iâ€™m assuming to get an idea of the position of the people. . . . What he did was he stuck his arm from the door jam to determine the length from the door jam to the middle of the head rest in the front.Â  He did the same thing in the back.Â  He stuck it, he put his arm, he was attempting to use the length of his arm to estimate distance is what it appeared to me.â€Â  

The solicitor, on the other hand, stated that he thought the juror was simply testing the tint of the car window.Â  
Appellant moved to have Juror M removed and an alternate juror seated.Â  The trial judge found Juror M had done nothing improper and denied the motion. Â Appellant contends Juror M should have been dismissed because he conducted his own experiment.
 A jury may be allowed to view the scene or pieces of evidence but it is improper for the jury to conduct its own experimentation.Â  Stone v. City of Florence, 203 S.C. 527, 28 S.E.2d 409 (1943).Â  The issue is what constitutes â€œexperimentationâ€ such that it rises to the level of juror misconduct.Â  Jurors will not be presumed guilty of misconduct and acts that are merely incidental to an assessment of the evidence are not improper.Â  Id.; see also State v. Buckhalter, 153 S.C. 487, 151 S.E.64 (1930) (not improper experimentation in trial for possessing contraband to allow jury to take liquor into jury room to smell or taste it).Â  However, an attempted re-enactment of the facts at issue will render a jurorâ€™s conduct improper. Â See, e.g., State v. Ballew, 83 S.C. 82, 63 S.E. 688 (1909)(jurors attempted to throw a hatchet against the wall of a jail cell to re-enact the prosecutorâ€™s description of the crime); Baroody v. Anderson, 195 S.C. 422, 11 S.E.2d 860 (1940) (jury asked the sheriff to drive his car around the curve where the wreck occurred at 35 mph in order to observe it approaching). 
We find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing to dismiss Juror M. Â See State v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 599 S.E.2d 448 (2004) (within trial judgeâ€™s discretion to substitute alternate juror).Â  First, it is not clear the juror was actually â€œtaking measurements,â€ as appellant claims, and we will not presume a juror engaged in misconduct.Â  There was no attempted re-enactment of the crime, rather Juror Mâ€™s actions were merely incidental to an assessment of the evidence.Â  Moreover, photographs in evidence show the carâ€™s back seat, where the bullet hole was, where the childâ€™s car seat was, and where Victim was sitting.Â  There is no real dispute regarding the measurements of the back seat such that any â€œmeasurementsâ€ by Juror M would have carried undue weight in jury deliberations. Â 
3.Â  Directed verdict on aggravating circumstance
Appellant moved for a directed verdict on the statutory aggravator provided in Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(3) which states:

That the offender by his act of murder knowingly created a great risk of death to more than one person in a public place by means of a weapon or device which normally would be hazardous to the lives of more than one person.

Appellant contends that because he shot Victim at close range and no other person was endangered, this aggravator should not apply as a matter of law.
 The trial judge should submit a statutory aggravator to the jury if there is any evidence, direct or circumstantial, to support it.Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000).Â  Here, the police department parking lot is clearly a public place and a gun is a weapon hazardous to more than one person.Â  Id. (shooting in church parking lot).Â  Further, appellant knew there were other occupants in the car with Victim when he shot multiple times into the confined space of the carâ€™s interiorâ€”conduct a reasonable person would know presents a great risk of harm to more than one person.Â  Appellant also pointed his gun at Officer Godfrey in the parking lot.Â  This evidence supports the submission of the statutory aggravator to the jury.
4.Â  Proportionality review
Appellant contends the imposition of death in his case is disproportionate to other death penalty cases because his case involves only a single victim and resulted from a domestic dispute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25 (2003) (proportionality review).Â  
 We find no support for appellantâ€™s attempt to reduce this crime to simply â€œa domestic dispute.â€Â  Appellantâ€™s culpability is not lessened by the fact that the victim was his wife.Â  There is no evidence of any immediate dispute leading up to the murder,[3] much less any provocation on Victimâ€™s part.Â  In fact, appellant intentionally violated a court order forbidding contact with Victim.Â  
Further, as discussed above, the evidence supports the submission of the aggravating factor in this case.Â  The legislature has determined that a unanimous verdict on only one aggravating factor is sufficient to support the death penalty.Â  There have been numerous capital cases where the jury found only a single aggravator and death was imposed.Â  See,e.g., State v. Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248 (2000) (killing police officer); State v. Rogers, 338 S.C. 435, 527 S.E.2d 101 (2000) (killing child under age of eleven); State v. Huggins, 336 S.C. 200, 519 S.E.2d 574 (1999) (armed robbery); Ray v. State, 330 S.C. 184, 498 S.E.2d 640 (1998) (kidnapping); State v. Atkins, 303 S.C. 214, 399 S.E.2d 760 (1990) (prior murder conviction). Â We find appellantâ€™s disproportionality argument without merit.Â  
We have reviewed the record and conclude the imposition of death in this case was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor, nor is it excessive or disproportionate to the penalty imposed in other cases.Â  The judgment of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Five shell casings were found but the fifth bullet was not recovered.Â  A paramedic testified for the defense that when he arrived on the scene to transport appellant to the hospital, appellant said he had shot himself in the head. 
[2] Appellant objected that seeing the car would be unfairly prejudicial because instead of focusing on the â€œspatial relationshipsâ€ in the car, the jury would be affected by the fact that Victim had been killed there.Â  
[3] Appellantâ€™s mother testified generally in the sentencing phase that appellant was upset he was not allowed to see his children.Â
