THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      South Carolina Department of Mental Health, Plaintiff/Petitioner,
      v.
      Henry Dargan McMaster, Attorney General of South Carolina, and The State Budget and Control Board, Defendants/Respondents.
    
  


IN THE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26269
Heard September 20, 2006 - Filed February 20, 2007


  
    
      
        Mark W. Binkley, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert D. Cook, Senior Assistant Attorney General Havird Jones, Jr., all of Columbia, for Respondent Henry Dargan McMaster, and Edwin E. Evans, Esquire, David K. Avant, and M. Richbourg Roberson, all of Columbia, for Respondent State Budget and Control Board. 
        Robert W. Hayes, Jr., of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae, National Alliance on Mental Illness.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We accepted this matter in our original jurisdiction to issue a declaratory judgment as to whether or not certain property owned by the Department of Mental Health (DMH), referred to as the â€œBull Street Property,â€ is held in a charitable trust and, if so, whether and under what conditions it may be sold.Â  We hold the property is subject to a charitable trust but may be sold in accordance with our discussion below.Â  
FACTS
The State Lunatic Asylum was created in 1821.[1]Â  The Act creating the Asylum implemented a board of seven trustees to be elected by the Legislature, â€œwho shall superintend the public institutions herby intended to be established.â€Â  1821 Acts No. 2269.Â  The following year, the General Assembly passed Act. No. 2286 of 1822 entitled, â€œAn Act to vest the title of the lot upon which the lunatic asylum stands, in the trustees and visiters of said asylum.â€Â  
â€œBull Street,â€ as it has become known, is made up of 185.6 acres, excepting approximately 4.5 acres which contain the Mills Building and surrounding grounds.Â  The Mills Building was the initial site of the asylum.Â Â  The property was originally 14 separate tracts of land, and was acquired by the DMH and its predecessors in a series of transactions occurring between the 1820â€™s and 1905.Â  The record contains deeds evidencing 12 of these transactions; the remaining 2 parcels were acquired prior to the 1860â€™s, and no deeds are available.Â  
Several of the deeds contain restrictive language requiring the property to be used â€œfor the use and purposes of the State Hospital for the Insane.â€Â  The initial two parcels, conveying a total of 31.5 acres, were conveyed to â€œThe Regents of the Lunatic Asylum of South Carolina, its successors and assigns forever.â€Â  The third parcel, comprising 50 acres, was conveyed to â€œThe Regents of the Lunatic Asylum of South Carolina, their successors in office, for their only proper use, benefit, and behoof, forever.â€ Â Parcels 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10 all grant property to the Regents of the State Hospital â€œand their successors and assigns forever for the use and purposes of the said State Hospital.â€Â  Each of the parcels was sold to the Board of Regents for a stated consideration, ranging from $5.00 (Parcel 15, .59 acres) to $24,500.00Â  (Parcel 8, 108.45 acres). Â Throughout the years, numerous properties owned by the State Hospital were sold to various entities, the proceeds generally going to the DMH.[2]Â  Most of these sales were authorized by the General Assembly and or the Budget and Control Board.Â  
In 2004, as part of the Appropriations Act, the General Assembly passed Proviso 73.18 to â€œestablish a comprehensive central property and office management facility process to plan for the needs of state government agencies and to achieve maximum efficiency and economy in the use of state owned or state leased real property.â€Â  Pursuant to the proviso, the Budget and Control Board was directed to identify all state owned properties and title to all such properties, excepting those the Board determined were subject to reverter clauses or other restraints upon transfer of title.Â  The proviso further states that, â€œ[u]pon a determination by the Board that a property should be sold, the agency is required to sell the property and remit the proceeds as directed herein.â€ 
In the 2005 Appropriations Act, the General Assembly enacted Proviso 63.40, which was vetoed by the Governor, but overridden by the Legislature.Â  Proviso 63.40 provides, in pertinent part: 

  Up to 50% of the proceeds, net of selling expenses, from the sale of surplus real properties shall be retained by the Budget and Control Board and used for the deferred maintenance of state-owned buildings. The remaining 50% of the net proceeds shall be returned to the agency that the property is owned by, under the control of, or assigned to and shall be used by that agency for non-recurring purposes. 

After inquiries as to whether some of the State Hospital properties could be sold for development, the Attorney General requested the Executive Director of the Budget and Control Board (Board) for his advice and conclusions as to whether there were any prohibitions or limitations on the sale of the Bull Street property, and whether it was encumbered by a charitable trust.Â  The Board responded as follows:

  The current thinking among experts practicing in the mental health field is that large complexes like the Bull Street site which isolate patients and separate them from their communities is not the best situation for the treatment and successful re-integration of patients into the general population.Â  The thinking is that the Bull Street tract is not specifically needed to house mental health facilities and that it would be more efficient and economical for the State and Department of Mental Health to sell this property, relocate facilities, and reinvest the proceeds that would be derived. . . .Â  

The Board noted the property upon which the Mills Building is situated was not included in any plans by the State to sell the property and would remain in State ownership.Â  The Board concluded the property was not encumbered by a charitable trust, such that it believed the General Assembly could authorize a sale of the property.Â  The Board concluded, however, that it would defer to the Attorney Generalâ€™s opinion on the matter.[3]Â Â  
In response, the Attorney General issued an opinion on December 9, 2005, concluding as follows: 

  [A] court would most likely conclude that the Department of Mental Health, as successor to the State Lunatic Asylum and South Carolina State Hospital for the Insane, is a â€˜public charityâ€™ and that the Bull Street property is thus impressed with a charitable trust. Accordingly, we recommend that prior to any sale, the Department of Mental Health seek court approval of such sale, consistent with the basic principle that a court of equity must approve, by way of equitable deviation, any such transfer.

The Attorney General stated that as an alternative, the Legislature could protect the charitable trust by requiring the proceeds from any sale to be devoted exclusively to the Department of Mental Health.
In light of the Attorney Generalâ€™s opinion, the DMH filed a petition for original jurisdiction as to whether the Bull Street property is encumbered by a charitable trust and, if so, whether and under what conditions the property may be sold.Â  We agree with the Attorney Generalâ€™s opinion that the property is subject to a charitable trust.Â  However, given the change in circumstances in the care and treatment of mental health patients, we hold the doctrine of equitable deviation may be employed to allow a sale of the property with disbursement of the proceeds to be placed in trust for the benefit of DMH.Â  
ISSUES

  1.Â  Is the Bull Street property held subject to a charitable trust for the benefit of the Department of Mental Health?
  2.Â  If Bull Street is subject to a charitable trust, under what circumstances may the property be sold, and to whom are the proceeds disbursed?

1.Â  CHARITABLE TRUST
This Court has recognized the benevolent purposes of the state hospital.Â  See Crouch v. Benet, 198 S.C. 185, 17 S.E.2d 320, 323 (1941) (holding that South Carolina was a pioneer of the southern states in the care of the insane which has been supported, maintained, and â€œpursuant to Acts of the Legislature and by means of appropriations for this most worthy, humane and beneficent purpose as a State Institution.â€ Moreover, institutions for the insane are constitutionally provided for and subject to regulation by the General Assembly.Â  Article 12, Â§ 1, CONST 1895.
A charitable trust is defined as: 

  [A] fiduciary relationship with respect to property arising as a result of a manifestation of an intention to create it, and subjecting the person by whom the property is held to equitable duties to deal with property for a charitable purpose.Â  Restatement (2nd) TrustsÂ  Â§ 348 (1959). . . .Â  The settlor must manifest an intention to create a charitable trust. Â It is not necessary that any particular words or conduct be manifest to create a trust, and it is possible to create a trust without using the words â€œtrustâ€ or â€œtrustee.â€

Scott on Trusts Â§Â§ 24--25 (2d Ed. 1956); Restatement (2nd) Trusts Â§ 24. Conversely, the mere fact these words are used, or other similar words, does not necessarily indicate an intention to create a trust.
In the 1922 case of Harter v. Johnson, 122 S.C. 96, 115 S.E. 217 (1922), the Court was called upon to interpret the will of a deceased physician who had, by his will, bequeathed â€œ[a]ll the residue of my estate, real and personal and mixed, . . . I give and devise, for the purpose of establishing, building and equipping a public hospital in the town of Fairfax, for the treatment of white and colored patients.â€Â  This Court, in addressing the issue of whether a charitable trust had been created, stated:

  Trusts for public charitable purposes, being for objects of permanent interest and benefit to the public, and perhaps being perpetual in their duration, are upheld under circumstances under which private trusts would fail. . . . 
  No formality in the use of language is necessary in order to create a public charitable trust. The courts look to the purpose for which the gift was made, rather than to the particular words used to designate that purpose. Â And while a gift cannot be sustained as a charity unless made upon a trust, either express or implied, that it shall be devoted to uses which the law recognizes as charitable, the omission from a bequest of the words in trust is not material, where the intention is clearly manifested that the whole property shall be applied by the legatee for the benefit of other persons than himself. . . . 
  [it] is said: â€˜The founding and maintenance of hospitals and asylums of various kinds, and homes for destitute and friendless children, and the aged and infirm, constitute charitable uses or trusts, and bequests, devises, or other gifts for such purposes will be upheld in equity with a strong hand. Trusts for such purposes may be established and carried into effect, when, if not of a charitable nature, they could not be supported.Â  

115 S.E.2d at 221-222.Â  The Court has similarly found the existence of a charitable trust in cases in which it has not been expressly stated.Â  See Watson v. Wall, 229 S.C. 500, 93 S.E.2d 918 (1956) (testamentary provision wherein testator directed that any surplus left after application of funds to specific purposes might be used to aid poor and indigent to obtain medical care and hospitalization in judgment of testator's executor or executors was not so indefinite or general as to be ineffectual to create a charitable trust); Porcher v. Cappelmann, 187 S.C. 491, 198 S.E. 8, 9 (1938) (valid charitable trust created where testatrix bequeathed residuary estate to a named trustee, â€œto be used and expended in such manner as he may deem wise in assistance in the City of Columbia, S. C., to crippled children, in the provision of medical and surgical attention to such children, purchase of medicines, braces or other appliances or any other article to assist and benefit said children, said work for crippled children to be conducted in the City of Columbia, S. C.â€).Â  
Further, as noted by the Attorney General, properties conveyed to a public charity are also impressed with a charitable trust.Â  See Wellesley College v. Attorney General, 313 Mass. 722, 49 N.E.2d 220 (1943); In Re Los Angeles County Pioneer Society, 257 P.2d 1, 9 (Ca. 1953) (â€œIn cases where . . . property is conveyed without restriction to a charitable corporation . . . the charitable intent of the donor is ascertained by reference to the charitable purposes of the donee.â€); In re Harringtonâ€™s Estate, 36 N.W.2d 577, 582 (Neb. 1949) (a gift or bequest by name, without further restriction or limitation as to use, to a corporation conducted solely for charitable purposes, will be deemed to have been made for the objects and purposes for which the corporation was organized); Brown v. St. Lukeâ€™s Hosp. Assn., 274 P.2d 740 (Colo. 1929) (St. Lukeâ€™s Hospital came into being as, and continued to remain, a charitable institution such that all property held or acquired by it was impressed with a trust for the charitable uses and purposes).
We find the Arizona Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion in Goddard v. Coerver, 412 P.2d 259 (Ariz. 1966), directly on point.Â  Like this case, Goddard involved land purchased for a state insane asylum.Â  In September 1885, the Board of Supervisors of Maricopa County, Arizona, purchased 160 acres of land for $3500.00Â  On October 8, 1885, this same 160 acres was conveyed by the Board of Supervisors to the Board of Directors of the Insane Asylum of Arizona.Â  The deed conveyed the property to the Directors â€œfor the use and benefit of the Territory of Arizona And for said Asylum.â€Â  412 P.2d at 261.Â  The deed went on to state, â€œfor the use and benefit of the Territory . . . , and for said asylum in accordance with the provisions of the said acts of said Legislature.â€Â  Id. at 262.Â  (Emphasis supplied).Â  However, the deed also purported to vest title in the directors, their assigns and successors, in fee simple absolute.Â  Id.Â  In 1965, the Asylum Board expressed an interest in selling 62 acres of the property to Maricopa County as a site for a new Maricopa County General Hospital.Â  At the time, the property was being put to agricultural purposes in support of the asylum.Â  The Arizona Supreme Court held the property had been conveyed to the Board of Directors in the form of a charitable trust.[4]Â Â  
As in Goddard, the property here was conveyed for the charitable purposes of the State Hospital for the Insane.Â  It was conveyed to the Board of Regents of the Hospital, and the General Assembly enacted enabling legislation specifically for the benevolent purpose of establishing a hospital for the insane.Â  The General Assembly also deemed fit that title to the property vest in the Board of Regents, and has routinely authorized the appropriation of funds for its charitable purposes.Â  We find that the deeds and the legislative acts giving rise to the State Hospital clearly evidence the creation of a charitable trust.Â  Accordingly, we find the property is held in trust for the DMH.Â  
2.Â  SALE OF PROPERTY
Property subject to a charitable trust may not be terminated or altered by the General Assembly, but rather, must be approved by the court.Â  Smith v. Moore, 225 F. Supp. 434 (D. E. Va. 1963) (legislature cannot terminate a charitable trust, nor seek to control its disposition under doctrine of cy pres;Â  however this does not mean that Legislature cannot properly reserve to the judicial branch the power to do so); see also Second Ecclesiastical Society of Hartford v. Attorney General, 48 A.2d 266 (Conn. 1946) (supervision of charitable trusts is an inherent judicial function and is not a matter for the legislature. Â As a court of equity, the court possesses the authority to carry out the intent of the donor of a charitable trust). 
This Court has previously applied the doctrine of equitable deviation, which â€œpermits deviation from a term of the trust if, owing to circumstances not known to the settlor and not anticipated by him, compliance would defeat or substantially impair the accomplishment of the purposes of the trust. Under these circumstances a court may direct or permit a trustee to accomplish acts that are unauthorized or even forbidden by the terms of the trust.â€Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 169, 616 S.E.2d 710, 716-717 (2005), citing Colin McK. Grant Home v. Medlock, 292 S.C. 466, 473, 349 S.E.2d 655, 659 (Ct.App.1986) (allowing trustees to deviate from original terms of charitable trust by selling six homes built in Charleston to serve needy, elderly, white Presbyterians and investing proceeds of sale with income distributed as housing subsidy to elderly, needy Presbyterians of all races).
Considerable flexibility will always be allowed in the details of the execution of a trust, so as to adapt it to the changed conditions.Â  Mars v. Gibert, 93 S.C. 455, 466, 77 S.E. 131, 135 (1913) (refusing to allow trustees of John de la Howe School to deviate from original terms of charitable trust contained in 1797 will by devoting funds to college scholarships instead of early education, but explaining trustees could establish a school at a different location, which could work in conjunction with public school system to teach agricultural and mechanical arts); All Saints Parish, Waccamaw v. Protestant Episcopal Church, 358 S.C. 209, 227, 595 S.E.2d 253, 263 (Ct.App.2004).
It is undisputed that the Bull Street property is no longer necessary to house mentally ill patients.Â  Accordingly, we find the doctrine of equitable deviation should be utilized to allow the property to be sold.Â  However, we hold that the proceeds from any sale of the property must remain in trust for the benefit of DMH for the care and treatment of the mentally ill.Â  
DECLARATORY JUDGMENT ISSUED.Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The preamble to the Act recognized,Â  â€œ. . . the benevolent purposes of society require, on the part of the State, a public institution for the reception and cure of lunatics, for the instruction of the deaf and dumb, and for the maintenance of the poor and destitute of either class.â€Â  
[2] Â No issue is before this Court concerning prior sales of Bull Street properties.Â  However, we note that our opinion today in no way affects or invalidates any prior sales, to which there has never been an objection.
[3]Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-7-130 (1976), the Attorney General is charged with the protection of public charities and is required to enforce the due application of funds given or appropriated to such charities.
[4]Â  In addition, the Court concluded that the unused portion of these lands could, consistent with the principles of equitable deviation, be approved by the court for reconveyance by the Hospital's board of directors to the county for construction of a general hospital.Â  The equitable deviation issue will be addressed below.

title: State v. Northcutt
description: Appellantâ€™s death sentence is reversed and remanded for further sentencing proceedings because of the solicitorâ€™s prejudicial closing argument and the inclusion of evidence of the victimâ€™s prior injury.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent
        v.
        Clinton Robert Northcutt, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26271
Heard October 17, 2006 - Filed February 20, 2007

REVERSEDÂ AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        David I. Bruck and Robert E. Lominack, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of the South Carolina Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

___________
JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Clinton Robert Northcutt (Appellant) was convicted of killing his infant daughter and sentenced to death.Â  We reverse and remand for a new sentencing proceeding.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Appellant, his wife, Angie, who was pregnant with their second child, and their four-month old daughter, Breanna, resided in Lexington County, South Carolina.Â  In early January 2001, Ms. Northcutt threatened to leave Appellant, but he took her car keys and prevented her from doing so.Â  Two days later, Appellant shook, squeezed, slapped, punched, bit, strangled, and beat his infant daughter to death in an apparent fit of rage when she would not stop crying.
Appellant fled the home and was arrested near Atlanta later that day.Â  Ms. Northcutt returned home from work that evening and found Appellantâ€™s wedding ring lying on a table and a message on the answering machine in which Appellant told his wife the baby was dead and apologized for what he had done.Â  He also told her he was leaving and going far away so he would no longer hurt anyone. Â Ms. Northcutt then found the babyâ€™s body in the crib, and called emergency personnel.Â  
 
An autopsy revealed severe and extensive trauma to the childâ€™s body and significant bruising, internal hemorrhaging, and bone fractures indicative of shaken baby syndrome.Â  According to the examining pathologist, more than one of the babyâ€™s injuries alone were potentially fatal.Â  He estimated the injuries were inflicted over a seven to fifteen minute time frame, although it could have been as little as two to three minutes.Â  He testified there were no old bruises or injuries on her body and that all injuries stemmed from this single event. 
 
The jury found Appellant guilty of murder.Â  In the sentencing phase the State introduced evidence in aggravation of punishment including: (1) suspensions and school vandalism by the Appellant when he was in middle school; (2) an incident, for which he served one year in the Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ), in which Appellant brought a loaded handgun to school; and (3) three disciplinary infractions Appellant committed during his two-and-a-half years in pre-trial confinement.Â  Appellant presented evidence in mitigation showing he suffered physical violence and emotional abuse at the hand of his alcoholic father who, at the time of Appellantâ€™s trial, was serving an eight-year prison sentence for sexually molesting Appellantâ€™s nine-year-old half-sister.Â  Evidence also showed Appellant failed to receive help or treatment from the Department of Social Services (DSS), despite numerous child abuse complaints and injuries to Appellant from the time he was age five until age fourteen.Â  The jury returned a death sentence.Â  
 
ISSUES

  
     I. 
    Did the trial judge err in denying Appellant’s request to submit homicide by child abuse as a lesser-included offense of murder?
	
  
  
    II.  
    Did the trial judge err in requiring Appellant to direct his expert witnesses to generate written reports for the prosecution?
	
  
  
    III. 
    Did the trial judge err in admitting evidence that the baby had suffered a broken leg at age ten-weeks while Appellant was removing her from a swing-seat, in the absence of any evidence that the injury was the result of child abuse?
	
  
  
    IV. 
    Did the trial judge err in admitting a letter from Ms. Northcutt to a defense social worker in which Ms. Northcutt stated she had “no sympathy” for Appellant?
	
  
  
    V.  
    Should Appellant have been permitted to introduce a letter to his wife expressing remorse for the death of their baby in response to the wife’s testimony that Appellant’s post-arrest phone calls to her had shown a lack of remorse and concern?
	
  
  
    VI. 
    Did the solicitor’s closing argument so infect the jury’s sentencing determination with passion and prejudice that it requires reversal of the death sentence?  
	 
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, this Court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973).Â  This Court is bound by the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Lesser-Included Offense
Appellant argues the trial judge erred in failing to submit homicide by child abuse as a lesser-included offense of the murder of a child under age twelve.Â  We disagree.
The indictment charged Appellant with the crime of murder under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 (Supp. 2005).Â  The State submitted a notice of evidence in aggravation of punishment listing the following statutory aggravators: (1) the murder was committed in the commission of physical torture; and (2) the victim was a child eleven years of age or under.[1]Â  
 
The test for determining whether a crime is a lesser included offense of the crime charged is whether the greater of the two offenses includes all the elements of the lesser offense.Â  Hope v. State, 328 S.C. 78, 492 S.E.2d 76 (1997). Â If the lesser offense includes an element not included in greater offense, then the lesser offense is not included in the greater.Â  Id.Â  
 
Homicide by child abuse requires proof of the death of a child under age eleven during the commission of child abuse or neglect and the death occurs under circumstances showing extreme indifference to human life.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-85 (2003).Â  Murder is the â€œkilling of any person with malice aforethought, either express or implied.â€Â  Id. Â§ 16-3-10.Â  
 
Homicide by child abuse is not a lesser included offense of murder.Â  An element of homicide by child abuse, the death of a child under age eleven, is not an element of murder.Â  Thus, the elements test has not been met.Â  â€œA lesser offense is included in the greater only if each of its elements is always a necessary element of the greater offense.â€Â  Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 81, 530 S.E.2d 887, overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).[2]
Â When an offense fails to meet the elements test, this Court will nevertheless construe it as a lesser included offense if the offense has traditionally been considered a lesser included offense of the greater offense charged.Â  State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 264, 589 S.E.2d 6, 8 (2003) (citing State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 563 S.E.2d 336 (2002)).Â  There is no historical antecedent suggesting homicide by child abuse is a lesser included offense of murder.Â  Because homicide by child abuse is not a lesser included offense of murder under either the elements test or the historical antecedent test, the trial judge did not err in denying Appellantâ€™s request to submit homicide by child abuse as a lesser included offense of murder.Â 
II.Â  Expert Reports
Appellant argues the trial judge erred by requiring him to direct his expert witnesses to generate written reports for the benefit of the prosecution.Â  We agree.Â  
 
Before trial, the State submitted a motion requesting the names and addresses of all potential expert witnesses upon whom Appellant intended to rely to establish a mental defense or â€œany other mental deficiency.â€Â  The State also requested Appellant â€œdisclose the conclusions and reports of any and all potential expert witnesses reduced to writing and accompanied by any and all written materials and all other materials upon which such an opinion is based.â€Â  The motion failed to cite any South Carolina rule governing pretrial discovery.Â  The trial judge ordered Appellant to comply with the Stateâ€™s request, noting the â€œstandard procedure has been to require both sides to produce reports.â€Â  
 
Rule 5(b)(1)(B) of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure creates a right of reciprocal discovery: 
 

  If the defendant requests disclosure under subdivision (a)(1)(C) or (D) of this rule, upon compliance with such request by the prosecution, the defendant, on request of the prosecution, shall permit the prosecution to inspect and copy any results or reports of physical or mental examinations and of scientific tests or experiments made in connection with the particular case, or copies thereof, within the possession or control of the defendant, which the defendant intends to introduce as evidence in chief at the trial or which were prepared by a witness whom the defendant intends to call at trial when the results or reports relate to his testimony.Â  
	 

The rule requires the production of reports â€œwithin the possessionâ€ of the defense.Â  However, it does not authorize the trial judge to require parties to generate written reports solely for the benefit of the opponent.Â  Therefore, the trial judge erred in requiring Appellant to direct his expert witnesses to prepare written reports for the prosecution.Â Â  
 
Determining the trial judge committed error is the first step of our analysis.Â  Next we must determine whether the error was harmless.Â  Franklin v. Catoe, 346 S.C. 563, 572, 552 S.E.2d 718, 723 (2001) (â€œthe harmless error rule and a prejudice analysis are no strangers to cases involving the death penaltyâ€).

  Whether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case. No definite rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case. Error is harmless when it â€œcould not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€

State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (citing State v. Key, 256 S.C. 90, 180 S.E.2d 888 (1971)).Â  
 
Appellant argues the State was unfairly benefited by the reports and was able to prosecute and cross-examine more vigorously because of the reports.Â  The State contends, and we agree, the written reports generated by Appellantâ€™s experts did not advantage the State any more than the notes, data, and other materials properly disclosed under Rule 5, SCRCrimP.Â  The written reports only summarized the contents of other discoverable materials.Â  
 
Appellant also argues the erroneous extension of Rule 5(b), S.C.R.Crim.P., by the trial judge resulted in the prejudicial exclusion of certain testimony from Dr. Tracy Gunter.Â  Dr. Gunter performed a family court-ordered evaluation of Appellant at DJJ in 1995.[3]Â  Although she diagnosed appellant with conduct disorder in 1995, she changed her diagnosis to Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder before the 2003 litigation in light of new information.Â  The trial judge excluded any testimony not related to the 1995 evaluation because Dr. Gunterâ€™s written report was based only on her 1995 encounter with Appellant. 
 
Although Dr. Gunterâ€™s entire testimony was critical in establishing mitigating evidence for Appellant, there was no prejudice to Appellant.Â  Dr. Gunter was able to convey the crux of her testimony by stating she was hampered in her evaluation of Appellant in 1995 by a lack of DSS records showing the abuse Appellant had endured at the hand of his father.Â  Dr. Gunter expressed concerns at the time of the evaluation that Appellant might have Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder or some type of dissociative disorder.Â  She further stated her 1995 diagnosis was not reliable or credible due to the lack of DSS records made available to her.Â  Because the erroneous extension of Rule 5, S.C.R.Crim.P., by the trial judge could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial, we conclude the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. 
 
III.Â  Evidence of the Babyâ€™s Prior Injury
Appellant argues the trial judge erroneously admitted evidence the baby suffered a broken leg at age ten-weeks when Appellant removed her from a swing-seat.Â  We agree. 
 
During the sentencing phase of Appellantâ€™s trial, the State introduced evidence that in October, 2000, nearly two months prior to the babyâ€™s death, Appellant accidentally injured her while removing her from a swing-seat.Â  The baby was diagnosed with and treated for a spiral fracture of the leg.Â  The diagnosis of such an injury at a hospital is a â€œred flagâ€ for possible child abuse; however, the treating physician did not refer the matter to DSS, the logical inference being the physician ruled out child abuse after treating the baby and meeting the parents.[4]Â  The State argued the fact Appellant caused the injury was sufficient to warrant the introduction of the evidence as relevant to the issue of his character and his relationship with his baby.Â  Appellant argued the jury would interpret â€œan accident that could have happened to anybodyâ€ as child abuse through â€œthe distorting lens of hindsight.â€Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
The admission of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000).Â  The trial judge abused his discretion in admitting evidence of the prior injury because it unfairly prejudiced Appellant.Â  Not only is such evidence arguably irrelevant, it is highly prejudicial and should have been excluded pursuant to Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Further, the error in admitting evidence the baby had suffered this injury was not harmless.Â  The Stateâ€™s purpose in introducing the evidence was to shed light on Appellantâ€™s relationship with the baby and to highlight the family tension that ensued during the two months prior to the babyâ€™s death.Â  The babyâ€™s prior injury was, under all accounts, an accident.Â  However, in light of Appellantâ€™s outburst of violence against his baby two months after this injury, the jury likely misperceived the evidence resulting in unfair prejudice to Appellant.Â  The erroneous admission of this evidence requires reversal of Appellantâ€™s death sentence.Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000) (in order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant).Â  
 
IV.Â  Letter from Ms. Northcutt
Appellant argues the trial judge erred by admitting a letter from Ms. Northcutt to a defense social worker in which Ms. Northcutt stated she had â€œno sympathyâ€ for Appellant.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
On cross-examination, Dr. Arlene Andrews, a defense social worker, testified she tried to talk with Ms. Northcutt about the parental care of the baby; however, Ms. Northcutt declined to be interviewed.Â  In an effort to impeach the witness, the solicitor read a letter written to Dr. Andrews by Ms. Northcutt in which Ms. Northcutt stated: â€œI have no sympathy for him and his actions, nor do I have any recollections or thought (sic) that would be sympathetic to him in any way.â€Â  The trial judge overruled Appellantâ€™s objection and allowed the letter into evidence.Â  
 
Appellant argues the State improperly introduced evidence of the victimâ€™s family memberâ€™s opinion in violation of Booth v. Maryland, 482 U.S. 496, 107 S.Ct. 2529, 96 L.Ed.2d 440 (1987), overruled on other grounds by Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808, 830 n.2, 111 S.Ct. 2597, 2611 n.2, 115 L.Ed.2d 720, 721 (1991) (â€œadmission of a victimâ€™s family membersâ€™ characterizations and opinions about the crime, the defendant, and the appropriate sentence violates the Eighth Amendmentâ€).Â  Expressing a lack of sympathy, however, does not offend the Booth proscription.Â  Rather than expressing her opinion of Appellant, Ms. Northcutt was responding to Dr. Andrewâ€™s inquiry. 
 
The trial judge did not err in admitting the letter from Ms. Northcutt to Dr. Andrews.Â  Even if the admission of the letter were error, the error was harmless.Â  In light of Ms. Northcuttâ€™s testimony and the record before us, the admission of the letter did not prejudice Appellant nor did it affect the result of the trial.Â  
 
V.Â  Letter from Appellant
Appellant argues he should have been permitted to introduce a letter he wrote to his wife expressing remorse for the death of their child in response to Ms. Northcuttâ€™s testimony that his post-arrest phone calls to her showed a lack of remorse and concern.Â  We agree.Â  
 
Ms. Northcutt testified of a series of phone calls she received from Appellant while he was in pre-trial confinement.Â  Ms. Northcuttâ€™s testimony implied Appellant never expressed concern for her or their deceased child or remorse for his actions.Â  On cross-examination, counsel for Appellant attempted to question her about a letter she received from Appellant nine days following the murder.Â  The letter written by Appellant expressed remorse and sorrow for his actions.Â  
 
The trial judge erroneously excluded the evidence. Â The prosecution had opened the door for Appellant to present evidence of his remorse.Â  Appellant is entitled to rebut the Stateâ€™s argument and correct the false impression the State conveyed to the jury.Â  The portion of the letter directly addressing Appellantâ€™s remorse was admissible.Â  The State cannot preclude the jury from considering â€œany relevant mitigating evidenceâ€ the defendant proffers in support of sentence less than death.Â  Payne, 501 U.S. at 822, 111 S.Ct. at 2606, 115 L.Ed.2d at 721 (citing Eddings v. Oklahoma, 455 U.S. 104, 114, 102 S.Ct. 869, 877, 71 L.Ed.2d 1, 1 (1982)).Â  The letter, as a whole, however, is subject to redaction because portions are inadmissible hearsay.[5]Â  A portion of the letter is admissible for the limited purpose of rebutting the Stateâ€™s argument Appellant had no remorse.
Although it was error for the trial judge to exclude the letter written from Appellant to Ms. Northcutt expressing remorse, the error was harmless.Â  The record contains evidence of Appellantâ€™s remorse.Â  Appellant was not prejudiced, nor was the outcome of the trial affected. 
 
VI.Â  Closing Argument
Appellant argues the solicitorâ€™s sentencing-phase closing argument so infected the juryâ€™s sentencing determination with passion and prejudice that it requires reversal of Appellantâ€™s death sentence.Â  We agree.Â  
 
A trial judge is vested with broad discretion in dealing with the range of propriety of closing argument, and ordinarily his rulings on such matters will not be disturbed. Â State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997).Â  We must review the argument in the context of the entire record. Â Id.Â  The appellant has the burden of showing that any alleged error in argument deprived him of a fair trial. State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 393 S.E.2d 364 (1990). The relevant question is whether the solicitorâ€™s comments so infected the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  Donnelly v. DeChristoforo, 416 U.S. 637, 94 S.Ct. 1868, 40 L.Ed.2d 431 (1974). Â Solicitors are bound to rules of fairness in their closing arguments as we explained in State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 312, 278 S.E.2d 335, 339 (1981):

  While the solicitor should prosecute vigorously, his duty is not to convict a defendant but to see justice done.Â  The solicitorâ€™s closing argument must, of course, be based upon this principle.Â  The argument therefore must be carefully tailored so as not to appeal to the personal bias of the juror nor be calculated to arouse his passion or prejudice.Â  
	 

We evaluate the closing argument in light of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) (2003) to determine â€œwhether the sentence of death was imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.â€
Appellant argues the solicitor violated this well-established rule by (1) crying numerous times throughout the argument; (2) telling the jury â€œwe will kick the baby some moreâ€ if they returned a life sentence; (3) dehumanizing Appellant (â€œI donâ€™t even call him a personâ€); (4) threatening the jury (â€œit will be on your heads if he kills someone else [during his life sentence in prison]â€); (5) declaring an â€œopen season on babies;â€ (6) telling the jury he â€œexpectsâ€ the death penalty; and (7) enacting a funeral procession complete with a black shroud covering the babyâ€™s crib.Â  
 
Three of the solicitorâ€™s arguments require reversal of the sentence.[6]Â  First, the solicitor suggested declaring an â€œopen season on babies in Lexington Countyâ€ if the death penalty was not returned.Â  The sole purpose of this statement was to inflame the jury.Â  The solicitor also repeatedly told the jury he â€œexpectsâ€ the death penalty and, in doing so, ignored our precedent which rebukes such an imposition of the solicitorâ€™s personal belief.[7]Â  Finally, he concluded his argument by producing a large black shroud and draping it over the babyâ€™s crib.Â  He wheeled the crib from the courtroom in a staged funeral procession.Â  
 
Any one of these three miscues requires reversal of Appellantâ€™s sentence.Â  The State admits the solicitorâ€™s comments constituted error, but contends the brutality of the crime and the fact Appellant himself asked for the death penalty require this Court uphold the sentence.[8]Â  While it is difficult to determine the impact of the evidence on the jury and the Appellantâ€™s own request for a death sentence, it is clear the solicitor was overly zealous in his argument.Â  State v. White, 246 S.C. 502, 507, 144 S.E.2d 481, 483 (1965) (â€œIn view of the absolute discretion of the jury with regard to the issue of mercy, it is impossible to determine whether the argument actually had a prejudicial effect upon the verdict.â€).Â  We conclude the solicitorâ€™s closing argument requires reversal of Appellantâ€™s death sentence because the sentence was imposed under the influence of passion and prejudice in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C).
CONCLUSION
Because of the solicitorâ€™s prejudicial closing argument and the inclusion of evidence of the childâ€™s prior leg injury, we reverse Appellantâ€™s death sentence and remand for further sentencing proceedings.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â   
MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion.
Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the trial court did not err in admitting evidence regarding the victimâ€™s prior leg injury.Â  Furthermore, I disagree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion that the solicitorâ€™s conduct during his closing argument rose to the level of a constitutional violation or otherwise requires reversal.
The relevant jurisprudence instructs that â€œthe Constitution requires the jury to make an individualized determination as to whether the defendant should be executed based on the â€˜character of the individual and the circumstances of the crime.â€™â€Â  Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808, 818 (1991) (quoting Booth v. Maryland, 482 U.S. 496, 502 (1987), and Zant v. Stephens, 462 U.S. 862, 879 (1983)).Â  Accordingly, it is well established that evidence which is probative of the defendantâ€™s character is admissible in a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  See State v. Gaskins, 284 S.C. 105, 124, 326 S.E.2d 132, 143 (1985)[9] (quoting Woodson v. North Carolina, 428 U.S. 280 (1976), and citing Barefoot v. Estell, 463 U.S. 880 (1983)).Â  In my view, this practice derives from the command that the decision to impose the death penalty be based on who the defendant is and what he has done.Â  In my opinion, the majority incorrectly posits that the evidence regarding the victimâ€™s prior leg injury was irrelevant and mistakenly concludes that this evidence, if admitted improperly, prejudiced Appellant.Â Â Â  
 
Of course, the evidence of the victimâ€™s prior leg injury was clearly relevant to Appellantâ€™s character.Â  The State did not offer the injury as evidence that Appellant was guilty of child abuse, but instead, offered the injury as evidence that Appellantâ€™s actions with his child, prior to his brutally murdering her, were occasionally reckless and callous.Â  The majorityâ€™s bald assertion that this evidence is â€œarguably irrelevantâ€ is unavailing.Â  
 
Furthermore, assuming, as the majority seems to, that Rule 403, SCRE, required the trial court to exclude this evidence as substantially more prejudicial than probative, I fail to see how this error prejudiced Appellant.[10]Â  Although Appellant may be correct in that the circumstances of this possibly accidental injury could have been viewed differently by the jury through the â€œdistorted lens of hindsight,â€ the trial court gave extensive instructions to the jury regarding this particular evidence, regarding evidence of character generally, and regarding the factors the jury was required to consider in deciding on the appropriate penalty in this case.Â  As this Court has noted, it is the duty of the jury to take the law from the court in the case on trial and â€œ[i]t must be presumed that they do so.â€Â  State v. Queen, 264 S.C. 515, 521, 216 S.E.2d 182, 185 (1975).Â  
 
The majorityâ€™s finding of prejudice in this case is all the more remarkable given the brutal events which were the subject of this sentencing proceeding.[11]Â  The solicitor referred to the victimâ€™s prior injury only once in his closing argument, remarking that it demonstrated that Appellant was not handling the victim â€œcarefullyâ€ and â€œlovinglyâ€ two months prior to the victimâ€™s death.Â  As a notable jurist once stated, â€œ[s]urely this brief statement did not inflame [the juryâ€™s] passions more than did the facts of the crime.â€Â  Payne, 501 U.S. at 831.Â  Furthermore, in the final testimony offered to the jury before the courtâ€™s charges, Appellant himself requested that the jury sentence him to death for the murder of his daughter.Â  In my view, Appellant has not demonstrated how any error the trial court committed in the admission of evidence prejudiced his case, and under these facts, I believe such a showing would indeed be a tall order.
The majority also concludes that three aspects of the solicitorâ€™s closing argument require reversal in this case â€œbecause the [death] sentence was imposed under the influence of passion and prejudice in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C).â€Â  I disagree.
As a primary matter, Appellant did not contemporaneously object to the solicitorâ€™s use of the black cloth and crib during closing argument.Â  Thus, Appellant did not preserve any argument for our review as it relates to this conduct.Â  See Varnadore v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 289 S.C. 155, 159, 345 S.E.2d 711, 714 (1986) (stating that â€œthe proper course to be pursued when counsel makes an improper argument is for opposing counsel to immediately object . . . .â€).
As I explained in my dissenting opinion in State v. Burkhart, Op. No. 26243 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Jan. 8, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 1 at 36), I believe this Courtâ€™s jurisprudence which suggests that Â§ 16-3-25(C) imposes a separate standard by which this Court should judge the conduct of capital sentencing proceedings is misguided and mistaken.Â  The soundness of my position as it would apply here is underscored by the fact that, when registering objections during the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, Appellant did not argue that the argument was improper under South Carolinaâ€™s statutory law.Â  Instead, Appellant argued that the solicitorâ€™s arguments â€œwere inflammatoryâ€ and â€œviolat[ed] the Eighth Amendment.â€Â  Perplexingly, the majorityâ€™s analysis begins by discussing the well-established constitutional guideposts that characterize capital jurisprudence, only to end with the naked conclusions that the argument was â€œoverzealousâ€ and in violation of a provision of the South Carolina Code.
The Eighth Amendment is violated when the decision to impose the death penalty is made in an arbitrary manner, or â€œout of a whim, passion, prejudice, or mistake.â€Â  Caldwell v. Mississippi, 472 U.S. 320, 329-30 (1985); State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 587, 300 S.E.2d 63, 72 (1982).Â  Violations of the Fourteenth Amendment occur when something â€œso infects the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€Â  See Darden v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 168, 181 (1986).Â  A trial court is vested with great discretion in dealing with the propriety of a closing argument to the jury, and, on appeal, a reviewing court must view the alleged impropriety of the closing argument in the context of the entire record.Â  State v. Woomer, 277 S.C. 170, 174-75, 284 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1981) (citing State v. Durden, 264 S.C. 86, 212 S.E.2d 587 (1975), and State v. Lindler, 276 S.C. 304, 278 S.E.2d 335 (1981)).
When viewed in the context of the entire record, I do not believe that the solicitorâ€™s comments so infected Appellantâ€™s sentencing proceeding with unfairness as to result in a denial of due process.Â  Regardless of whether the majority is correct in its assertion that the sole purpose of the solicitorâ€™s â€œopen seasonâ€ comment was to inflame the jury, the relevant inquiry is whether the argument, taken as a whole, resulted in a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.
Likewise, I disagree with the assertion that the solicitorâ€™s remark in which he expressed that he expected the death penalty requires reversal.Â  The solicitorâ€™s closing argument fills thirty-five pages of the record.Â  I seriously doubt that either of these two comments, each filling only one line on separate pages of the record, permeated the sentencing proceeding with any degree of unfairness.
The majority cites two cases as examples of jurisprudence from this Court â€œrebuk[ing]â€ such an imposition of the solicitorâ€™s personal belief into a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  As I stated in my Burkhart dissent, these cases are but examples of a line of this Courtâ€™s precedent which is based upon what I believe is a skewed reading of Â§ 16-3-25(C).Â  Of course, the introduction of overly inflammatory evidence as well as arguments which impermissibly appeal to the passions or prejudices of a jury have the potential to violate the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments.Â  Interestingly, the relevant federal precedent rejects a steadfast rule of reversal whenever â€œpersonal opinionâ€ is injected into a closing argument in a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  See Darden, 477 U.S. at 178 n.8, 181-82 (affirming, on habeas corpus review, a death sentence over the claim that the prosecutorâ€™s remark that he believed the state had carried its burden to support such a penalty violated the Fourteenth Amendment).Â  At least from a constitutional perspective, we have nonchalantly adopted a rule that the United States Supreme Court has rejected.
Affirming a conviction which follows an argument containing improper components is an unpleasant task.Â  Appellantâ€™s sentencing proceeding was not perfect, but few are.Â  On the record presented for our review, however, I cannot conclude that Appellantâ€™s sentencing proceeding was fundamentally unfair.Â  Our jurisprudence unwaveringly provides that we are to presume that juries follow their instructions and that proper instruction of the jury by the court cures most errors.Â  See State v. Ard , 332 S.C. 370, 386, 505 S.E.2d 328, 336 (1998) (citing State v. Pierce, 289 S.C. 430, 346 S.E.2d 707 (1986)).[12]Â  Instead of following this jurisprudence in the capital arena, I believe we have ignored it.Â  We ought to be more dutiful and genuine in our analysis.Â  The jury was instructed that it was the sole finder of facts in the proceeding; that it was to give Appellant every benefit of every reasonable doubt; that the burden of proof rested entirely upon the State; and that the jury was to make its decision dutifully, fairly, impartially, without passion, without prejudice, and without excessive emotion.Â  I would presume that the jury followed these instructions, and I would find that the juryâ€™s verdict calling for the death penalty was not imposed in violation of the Eighth Amendment.Â  
 
For the foregoing reasons, I would hold that even if the trial court erred in admitting evidence relating to the victimâ€™s prior injury, Appellant has not shown prejudice to warrant reversal of his sentence.Â  Also, I would hold that the solicitorâ€™s closing argument was not so improper as to violate the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse appellantâ€™s capital sentence but write separately because I would decide certain issues differently.Â  
 
Specifically, I view the admission of Ms. Northcuttâ€™s letter to Dr. Andrews as error, and would find the solicitorâ€™s closing argument improper in at least one aspect deemed acceptable by the majority.Â  As to the letter, I find Ms. Northcuttâ€™s reason for declining to speak with Dr. Andrews simply irrelevant. See e.g., State v. Burkhart, Op. No. 26243 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Jan. 8, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 1 at 36), (evidence in the sentencing phase must be relevant to the defendantâ€™s character or the circumstances of the crime).Â  As to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, in my view it was improper for him to argue the jury would be responsible for any future criminal acts of appellant if a life sentence were returned.Â  This argument, which projects personal responsibility upon jurors and plays to their fear, â€œinjects an arbitrary factorâ€ into the sentencing decision.Â  State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 577 S.E.2d 438 (2003).Â  I cannot agree with the majority that it was a â€œpermissible argument . . . based on the record and reasonable inferences from it.â€Â  Technically, perhaps, the crying, the â€œkick the baby some more,â€ and the dehumanizing of appellant arguments are within allowable parameters, but it is beyond dispute that the closing argument here repeatedly transgressed firmly established boundaries and precedents. It does not serve justice for a prosecutor to engage in such histrionic gamesmanship, especially where a jury is being asked to make a life or death decision.Â Â  
 
With these qualifications, I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse appellantâ€™s capital sentence and remand the matter for a new proceeding.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(h) and (10) (2003).
[2]Â  Compare State v. Mitchell, 362 S.C. 289, 296, 608 S.E.2d 140, 144 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe crime of homicide by child abuse only applies in cases where the decedent is under the age of eleven whereas the application of involuntary manslaughter is not affected by the age of the decedent.â€); State v. Elliott, 475 S.E.2d 202, 218 - 219 (N.C. 1996) (â€œ[F]irst-degree murder and felony child abuse each â€˜requires proof of a fact which the other does not.â€™â€) (citation omitted); State v. Molina, 713 N.W.2d 412, 432 (Neb. 2006) (â€œIt is clear â€¦ that child abuse resulting in death requires proof of an element that second degree murder does not: that the death was that of a minor child.â€).Â  
 
[3] Â Appellant was at DJJ because he had been found delinquent on a charge of bringing a firearm to school. 
 
[4]Â  The pathologist who performed the babyâ€™s autopsy noted a healing fracture of the femur.Â  He stated such an injury is â€œone of the signals to the emergency room and to pediatricians to investigate the possibility of child abuse.â€Â  He presumed an investigation had occurred here and multiple physicians had considered and ruled out child abuse as the cause of the babyâ€™s injury.Â  
 
[5]Â  Appellant fails to cite any exception to the hearsay rule which would allow the introduction of the entire letter. Appellantâ€™s reliance on Rule 803(3), SCRE, is misplaced because the letter does not qualify as Appellantâ€™s then existing state of mind.Â  
 
Â Also, Appellantâ€™s reliance on State v. Cabrera-Pena, 361 S.C. 372, 605 S.E.2d 522 (2004), is misplaced.Â  In Cabrera-Pena, the Court applied the â€œrule of completenessâ€ to allow the defendant to develop the full substance of a conversation when the prosecution witness testified to only portions of the conversation.Â  The instant case lacks the contemporaneous quality of the conversation in Cabrera-Pena.Â  
 
[6]Â  The first four alleged mistakes are permissible arguments because they were based on the record and reasonable inferences from it.Â  See State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 468 S.E.2d 620 (1996) (â€œA solicitorâ€™s closing argument â€¦ should stay within the record and reasonable inferences to it.â€).
[7]Â  See State v. Smart, 278 S.C. 515, 299 S.E.2d 686 (1982) (reversing a death sentence because of the same error by the same solicitor), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991); Thompson v. Aiken, 281 S.C. 239, 315 S.E.2d 110 (1984) (finding prejudicial error where prosecutorâ€™s argument put his personal opinion before the jury regarding the death penalty in murder cases and requiring a new sentencing proceeding).
[8]Â  After the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, Appellant told the jury: â€œI killed a defenseless, helpless, four-month-old baby, my daughter.Â  All I ask is do the right thing and bring back the right sentence.Â  Under the law, that would be the death sentence.â€Â  
 
[9] Overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 70 n.13, 406 S.E.2d 315, 329 n.5 (1991).
[10] I note that such an assumption is odd given that we have said that an abuse of discretion occurs only when the trial courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law or where its order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.Â  Renney v. Dobbs House, Inc., 275 S.C. 562, 564, 274 S.E.2d 290, 291 (1981) (citing Stewart v. Floyd, 274 S.C. 437, 265 S.E.2d 254 (1980)). 
 
[11] As the record reveals, in administering the beating which ultimately took the life of the four month old victim, Appellant slapped the victim with such force that his wedding ring left marks on the victimâ€™s scalp, punched the victim, choked the victim, shook the victim, bit the victim with such force that it left an imprint in the victimâ€™s bone, threw the victim on nearby household furniture, and ultimately broke the victimâ€™s back across the railing of the victimâ€™s crib.Â  
 
[12] Though not relevant to my analysis, Ard was overruled on other grounds by State v. Shafer, 340 S.C. 291, 304 n.12, 531 S.E.2d 524, 531 n.12 (2000).Â  Similarly, Pierce was overruled on other grounds by Torrence, 305 S.C. at 70 n.13, 406 S.E.2d at 329 n.5 (1991).

title: Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach
description: The Court affirmed the decision of the Court of Appeals to reinstate the Zoning Board of Appealsâ€™ denial of Petitionerâ€™s application.  The Court also held Petitionerâ€™s procedural due process rights were not violated and estoppel did not apply to prevent the City from alleging Petitionerâ€™s sign was nonconforming.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Clear Channel Outdoor, f/k/a Eller Media, Petitioner,
        v.
        The City of Myrtle Beach, and The City of Myrtle Beach Board of Zoning Appeals, Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Horry County
Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26272
Heard January 4, 2007 - Filed February 20, 2007Â   

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Howell V. Bellamy, Jr., and Douglas M. Zayicek, both of Bellamy, Rutenberg, Copeland, Epps, Gravely & Bowers, P.A., of Myrtle Beach, for Petitioner.
        Frances I. Cantwell, and William B. Regan, both of Regan and Cantwell, LLC, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Clear Channel Outdoor (Petitioner) filed an application with the Zoning Administrator for the City of Myrtle Beach (the City) to replace its billboard.Â  The application was denied.Â  The Cityâ€™s Zoning Board of Appeals (the Board) upheld the Zoning Administratorâ€™s denial of the application.Â  The circuit court initially upheld the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  The circuit court later vacated its first order and reversed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed.Â  We granted Petitionerâ€™s writ of certiorari to review Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 360 S.C. 459, 602 S.E.2d 76 (Ct. App. 2004), and we affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 6, 2001, a tornado destroyed a billboard owned and operated by Petitioner.Â  Petitioner applied for a permit to replace the billboard and the Zoning Administrator for the City denied the permit based on Section 902.9.1 of the cityâ€™s zoning ordinances.Â  Section 902.9 was adopted in February 1998.Â  It prohibits the construction of new billboards.Â  
 
Petitioner appealed to the Board, maintaining its billboard did not qualify as a new billboard, but as a replacement of an existing, conforming sign.Â  Petitioner argued the replacement of the billboard would not violate Section 902.9.1â€™s prohibition of new signs.Â  Petitioner emphasized the billboard was conforming prior to its destruction according to the Cityâ€™s own inventory of billboards.Â  Petitioner argued the permit should not be denied because it did not receive notice pursuant to Section 902.4.6 that its sign was in disrepair. Â Petitioner also argued that under Section 902.4.6.e, it had the right to restore, reconstruct, alter or repair the billboard as long as the reconstructed billboard conformed with all provisions of the current zoning ordinances.Â  
 
The City argued the billboard was nonconforming prior to its destruction.Â  This nonconformance was not discovered until the City inspected the site of the billboard after it was removed[1].Â  Upon inspection, the City determined the billboard was actually two billboards inches apart in violation of Section 902.7.2.c.2 which prohibits the placement of billboards within 750 feet of one another.Â  Section 902.8.3.d[2], therefore, applied to prevent the reconstruction of the billboard.Â  
 
The City claimed it relied on Section 902.7.2.c.2 merely as a reply to Petitioner and the only section applicable to the controversy was Section 902.9.1.Â  The City regarded Petitionerâ€™s application as one for a new billboard and not one to repair an existing billboard because there was nothing left to repair after Petitioner completely removed the destroyed billboard.Â  The Zoning Administrator stated: 
 

  I canâ€™t approve a permit to erect a billboard in the city â€¦.Â  I could only issue a permit as long as [the proposed billboard] complied with all the other provisions of the ordinance and thereâ€™s no way it could comply with 902.9.1 because that says there are no more billboards in the city.Â  
	 

The Zoning Administrator also claimed Section 902.9.1 rendered all existing billboards nonconforming.Â  She noted, however, Petitionerâ€™s billboard had not been placed on an amortization schedule as had other nonconforming billboards.Â  
 
The Board affirmed the Zoning Administrator and based the denial of the permit on Sections 902.9, 902.4.6, and 902.8.3.Â  Petitioner appealed to the circuit court, arguing the Board erred by considering ordinances other than Section 902.9.1 when Section 902.9.1 was the Zoning Administratorâ€™s only basis for denying the permit. Â The circuit court affirmed but subsequently vacated its order, agreeing with Petitioner that â€œSection 902.9.1 was the sole basis for the Zoning Administratorâ€™s denial of a permit, and no other issue was properly before the Boardâ€¦.â€Â  
 
Respondent appealed and the Court of Appeals reversed.Â  Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 360 S.C. 459, 602 S.E.2d 76 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Court of Appeals held the circuit court erred in limiting the Boardâ€™s review to Section 902.9.1 and noted â€œfew restrictions encumber the scope of the Boardâ€™s authority.â€Â  Id. at 465, 602 S.E.2d at 79.Â  The Court of Appeals cited S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800(E) (Supp. 2005) which confers upon the Board â€œall the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken.â€Â  Id.Â  The Court of Appeals also held Petitioner did not have a vested right to reconstruct a billboard.Â  Id. at 467, 602 S.E.2d at 80.Â  
 
ISSUES

  Did the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision violate Petitionerâ€™s procedural due process rights and is the City estopped from alleging Petitionerâ€™s sign was nonconforming when Petitioner allegedly had no notice of the nonconformity issue?Â  
	 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840(A) (Supp. 2005), â€œ[t]he findings of fact by the board of appeals must be treated in the same manner as a finding of fact by a jury, and the court may not take additional evidence.â€Â  In reviewing questions presented on appeal, the court must determine only whether the decision of the board is correct as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  A court will refrain from substituting its judgment for that of the reviewing body, even if it disagrees with the decision.Â  Rest. Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 335 S.C. 209, 216, 516 S.E.2d 442, 446 (1999).Â  However, a decision of a city zoning board will be overturned if it is arbitrary, capricious, has no reasonable relation to a lawful purpose, or if the board has abused its discretion.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision violates its procedural due process rights because Petitioner allegedly had no notice of the issues decided by the City.Â  Petitionerâ€™s argument fails because it had actual notice of the nonconformity issue and, therefore, the City is not estopped from alleging Petitionerâ€™s sign was nonconforming.
Due process requires (1) adequate notice; (2) adequate opportunity for a hearing; (3) the right to introduce evidence; and (4) the right to confront and cross-examine witnesses.Â  In re Vora, 354 S.C. 590, 595, 582 S.E.2d 413, 416 (2003).Â  Petitioner argued its due process rights were violated because it neither received notice of the nonconformity issue nor had a meaningful opportunity to be heard.Â  We disagree. 
 
First, the record contains a memorandum from Petitioner to the Zoning Administrator written prior to the hearing before the Board in which Petitioner expresses its understanding that its billboard was nonconforming under Section 902.9.1.Â  An affidavit from Petitionerâ€™s real estate manager confirms it knew of the nonconformity issue prior to the hearing before the Board.Â  Second, Petitioner affirmatively argued before the Board that its billboard was conforming.Â  The Record shows Petitioner had both notice of the nonconformity issue and an opportunity to be heard.Â  Petitionerâ€™s due process rights, therefore, were not violated.Â  
 
Petitionerâ€™s estoppel argument also fails.Â  Petitioner argues the City is estopped from finding Petitionerâ€™s sign is nonconforming because the City inspected the sign and determined it was conforming, and because the City failed to notify Petitioner of any nonconformity.Â  According to Petitioner, the City inspected all signs within the City limits and kept an inventory showing Petitionerâ€™s sign was conforming.Â  The inventory led Petitioner to believe its sign was conforming and deprived Petitioner of the opportunity to cure any defect before the sign was destroyed.Â  The City, on the other hand, maintains the inventory was merely an unofficial, staff-maintained record that predated Section 902.9.1.Â  
 
To claim equitable estoppel, a party must show: â€œ(1) a lack of knowledge and the means of knowledge of truth as to facts in question; (2) justifiable reliance upon the conduct of the party estopped; and (3) prejudicial change in the position of the party claiming estoppel.â€Â  Evins v. Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 532 S.E.2d 876 (2000).Â  Petitioner is charged with knowledge of the law.Â  See Labruce v. City of North Charleston, 268 S.C. 465, 234 S.E.2d 866 (1977). Petitioner was in the business of outdoor advertising and had ample means of knowing its sign violated the Cityâ€™s ordinance.Â  Section 902.9.1 has been in effect since 1998.Â  An unofficial inventory list does not excuse Petitioner from knowledge of ordinances which have a direct bearing on its business.Â  Petitioner knew or had means to know its sign was nonconforming under Section 902.9.1.Â  Therefore, Petitionerâ€™s reliance on the doctrine of estoppel is misplaced. 
 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â  We also affirm Petitionerâ€™s remaining issues pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Issues 1 and 2: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800(A), (E) (Supp. 2005); Â Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman,  309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is that words used therein must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand its operation.â€); Issues 4 and 5: Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 490, 454 S.E.2d 912, 918 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œWhile a property owner has a constitutionally protected right to continue the use following enactment of a zoning ordinance, provisions terminating the nonconforming use upon destruction of a specified portion of the premises â€¦ are proper, so long as the maximum amount of destruction permitted and the time allowed is reasonable.â€); and Issues 7 and 8: Purdy v. Moise, 223 S.C. 298, 302, 75 S.E.2d 605, 607 (1953) (â€œ[A local zoning boardâ€™s] construction of its own ordinance, the enforcement of which it is charged with, should be given some consideration and not overruled without cogent reason therefore.â€); Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987) (â€œThe circuit court should not disturb the findings of the board unless the board has acted arbitrarily or in an obvious abuse of discretion, or unless the board has acted illegally or in excess of its lawfully delegated authority.â€).
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justices James W. Johnson, Jr. and L. Casey Manning, concur.

[1] Â An employee for Petitioner removed the billboard out of concern for the dangerous condition resulting when the billboard was destroyed by a tornado.Â  
 
[2] Â Section 902.8.3 states, in pertinent part, â€œ[t]he right to maintain any nonconforming sign shall terminate and shall cease to exist whenever the sign structure is destroyed, or is damaged as described in subsection 902.4.6.eâ€¦.â€Â  Section 902.4.6.e states that a sign is damaged when the structural support has failed either by fracture or by exceeding its yield point.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
  

Gary L. Wise, Appellant,
 v.
 South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.

ORDER

By order dated October 12, 2006, this appeal was dismissed by the Court of Appeals. On October 27, 2006, the Court of Appeals received a petition to reinstate from appellant; however, he failed to provide proof of service. The remittitur was sent to the lower court by order dated October 30, 2006.
 On December 28, 2006, appellant filed a motion for enlargement of time in this Court. By order dated January 4, 2007, the motion was denied because the sending of the remittitur ended appellate jurisdiction over the matter.
 Appellant has now filed a “59(e) Motion to Alter or Amend a Judgement [sic],” an affidavit and memorandum of law in support of appellant’s “Notice of Right to Appeal,” and a document that we have construed as a petition for a writ of certiorari.
 Whenever it appears that an appellant has failed to comply with the requirements of the SCACR, an order of dismissal shall be issued. Rule 231(a), SCACR. The Clerk of Court shall remit the case to the lower court in accordance with Rule 221, SCACR, unless a motion to reinstate the appeal has been actually received by the court within fifteen days of filing of the order of dismissal. Id.
 When the remittitur has been properly sent, the appellate court no longer has jurisdiction over the matter and no motion can be heard thereafter. Mickle v. Blackmon, 255 S.C. 136, 177 S.E.2d 548 (1970); Thomas v. Lynch, 87 S.C. 44, 68 S.E. 817 (1910); Carpenter v. Lewis, 65 S.C. 400, 43 S.E. 881 (1903); State v. Keels, 39 S.C. 553, 17 S.E. 802 (1893). The only exception to this rule is when the remittitur is sent down by mistake, error or inadvertence of the Court. Keels, supra. 
 The remittitur in this case was not sent down by mistake, error or inadvertence of the Court of Appeals. Instead, it was correctly sent after fifteen days had elapsed from the date of the order dismissing the appeal without the proper filing of a petition for reinstatement. See Rule 224, SCACR (certificate of service shall be filed with all motions and petitions). Accordingly, this Court does not have jurisdiction to act in this matter. The documents filed by appellant are hereby dismissed.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.
