text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
B&A Development, Inc.; Baker-Haynes, LLC; H&C Fishers, Inc.; Charles C. Smith; James P. Mayes, III; Barry C. Haynes; Rachelle H. Hayes; Samuel H. Baker; Jody J. Baker; Andrew D. Smith;
G.D. Rogers; Mary G. Collins; Individually and as Class Representative for all those similarly situated,
Petitioners,
v.
Georgetown County, a Body Politic; Georgetown County Council; Georgetown County School District; Edna Earle Freeman in her capacity as Georgetown County Auditor; and Loretta D. Washington, in her capacity as Georgetown County Treasurer,
Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26273
Heard January 17, 2007 - Filed February 26, 2007Â 

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Gene M. Connell, Jr., of Kelaher, Connell & Connor, of Surfside Beach, for Petitioners.
David J. Mills, of McNair Law Firm, of Georgetown; David T. Duff, of Duff Turner White & Boykin, of Columbia; and Thomas J. Rubillo, of Georgetown, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: The Court granted petitionersâ€™ request for a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in B & A Dev., Inc. v. Georgetown County, 361 S.C. 453, 605 S.E.2d 551 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm as modified. 
FACTS
Petitioners are a group of individual and corporate taxpayers who filed suit in circuit court alleging that Georgetown County had unlawfully imposed excessive taxes on their real and personal property. Â Petitioners sought relief in the form of a refund or tax credit.Â  Regarding the underlying facts alleged by petitioners, the Court of Appeals appropriately summarized as follows:

In Georgetown County, the amount of the annual property tax assessment depends to a large degree on the amount of money the School District determines it needs for operations in the coming [] year. Â The process is straightforward: After the School District prepares its budget, the County auditor sets the tax rate, expressed in mills, to provide the necessary revenue to fund School District operations.
[Petitioners] contend the County has levied upon property owners a higher millage rate than was needed to supply the revenue requested by the School District. Â [Petitioners] allege this excess tax has created an illegal surplus each year from approximately 1991 until the time this lawsuit was filed in 2001. They claim the cumulative amount of the surplus collections exceeds $28 million.

B & A Dev., 361 S.C. at 456, 605 S.E.2d at 552.
Essentially, therefore, petitioners alleged a case of excessive millage; in addition, they captioned the case as a class action.Â  The circuit court dismissed the action, without prejudice, because petitioners had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies under the South Carolina Revenue Procedures Act (the RPA).[1]Â  On appeal, the Court of Appeals found that the RPA applied to petitionersâ€™ claims and therefore affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal.Â Â  B & A Dev., supra.Â  
ISSUES

1. Did the Court of Appeals err by affirming the circuit courtâ€™s decision that petitioners are required to exhaust their administrative remedies under the RPA?Â  
2. Have the rights of the class action plaintiffs been compromised by the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion?Â  Â  

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Applicability of the RPA
Petitioners raise the following arguments as to why the Court of Appeals erred in finding the RPA applies to the instant case:Â  (1) their dispute is with the Georgetown County School District, not the Department of Revenue; (2) S.C. Code Ann. section 12-43-285, specifically dealing with excessive millage rates, entitles a taxpayer to bring an action directly in circuit court; and (3) excessive millage claims were not thought to be properly brought under the RPA until the Courtâ€™s decision in Brackenbrook N. Charleston, LP v. County of Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 602 S.E.2d 39 (2004).Â  In addition, petitioners claim that the RPA does not provide taxpayers with a clear and certain remedy, and therefore, the Court of Appeals erred in finding that their claim did not challenge the constitutionality of the RPA.Â  Finally, petitioners assert that the law was unclear before Brackenbrook and that the decision should only be applied prospectively.Â  In our opinion, however, the lower courts correctly decided that the RPA applies.
The RPA was enacted in 1995; the express intent of the Act states as follows:Â  â€œIt is the intent of the General Assembly to provide the people of this State with a straightforward procedure to determine any dispute with the Department of Revenue. Â The [RPA] must be interpreted and construed in accordance with, and in furtherance of, that intent.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-20 (Supp. 2006).Â  Furthermore, the RPA clearly states â€œthere is no remedy other than those provided in this chapter in any case involving the illegal or wrongful collection of taxes, or attempt to collect taxes.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-80(A) (Supp. 2006) (emphasis added).Â  Indeed, the RPA specifies that if a taxpayer brings an action under the Act in circuit court, â€œthe circuit court shall dismiss the case without prejudice.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-3390 (Supp. 2006). Â The only exception to the exclusivity of administrative remedy is that an action for a declaratory judgment may be brought in circuit court â€œwhere the sole issue is whether a statute is constitutional;â€ this exception, however, does not apply to a claim that the statute is unconstitutional â€œas applied.â€ Â Id. Â§ 12-60-80(B); see also Ward v. State, 343 S.C. 14, 538 S.E.2d 245 (2000) (because an administrative law judge cannot rule on the constitutionality of a statute, a declaratory judgment action seeking to determine whether a statute is constitutional should not be dismissed by the circuit court).
In Brackenbrook, which also involved a claim of excessive millage, this Court stated that although the RPA contains many procedures for taxpayers challenging their property tax assessments, â€œrelief under the Act is not limited to these types of protests.â€ Â Brackenbrook, 360 S.C. at 398, 602 S.E.2d at 44.Â  Specifically, the Brackenbrook Court noted that the RPA allows a taxpayer to seek a refund of paid taxes under section 12-60-2560;[2] therefore, the Court held that the taxpayersâ€™ remedy was not a â€œdirect circuit court refund suit, but rather an administrative refundâ€ pursuant to section 12-60-2560.Â  Id. at 398-99, 602 S.E.2d at 44.
This case is not distinguishable from Brackenbrook, and thus, the Court of Appeals properly affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of the action pursuant to section 12-60-3390.Â  Petitioners allege that Georgetown County collected both real and personal property taxes based upon an excessive millage rate thereby resulting in an overcollection of taxes allocated to the school district.Â  The RPA provides an administrative remedy in the form of a refund for both real and personal property taxes.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 12-60-2560, 12-60-2940[3] (2000).Â  Thus, pursuant to both Brackenbrook and the plain language of the RPA, see Â§Â§ 12-60-20 & 12-60-80, petitioners must exhaust their administrative remedies before proceeding to circuit court.Â  
Accordingly, the Court of Appeals properly affirmed the dismissal.
We now turn to petitionersâ€™ specific arguments and address them briefly.Â  First, petitioners attempt to distinguish their county-based tax suit from the RPAâ€™s language regarding â€œany dispute with the Department of Revenue.â€ Â Â§ 12-60-20.Â  With respect to this contention, the Court of Appeals stated the following:Â  

In 1995, the Legislature adopted the RPA with the express legislative intent â€œto provide the people of this State with a straightforward procedure to determine any disputed revenue liability.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-20 (2000) (emphasis added). In 2000, the Legislature substituted the phrase â€œdispute with the Department of Revenueâ€ for â€œany disputed revenue liabilityâ€ in Â§ 12-60-20. Â See Â§ 12-60-20 (Supp. 2003). Â Our supreme court has noted that this alteration did not affect the applicability of the RPA to county tax protest procedures: 
  
Although this amendment could be read as indicative of an intent to limit the Act to tax issues involving the DOR, when amending Â§ 12-60-20 the legislature did not amend or repeal those parts of the Act which deal solely with county tax disputes. In light of this, we hold that a court must look first to the Act when faced with a question of county tax protest procedures. 
  

B & A Dev., 361 S.C. at 457 n.1, 605 S.E.2d at 553 n.1 (quoting Brackenbrook, 360 S.C. at 395, 602 S.E.2d at 42).Â  Looking at the RPA, we find the Act clearly envisions protests to county assessments.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 12-60-30, 12-60-2560, 12-60-2940 (including definitions and references to county auditor, county assessor, and county board of assessment appeals).Â  In addition, as noted by the Court of Appeals, the Brackenbrook decision itself provides clear support that a county-based excessive millage claim may not be initiated in circuit court.
Second, petitioners argue that because they are basing their lawsuit on S.C. Code Ann. section 12-43-285, the RPA does not apply.Â  This section states in relevant part:

If a millage rate is in excess of that authorized by law, the county treasurer shall either issue refunds or transfer the total amount in excess of that authorized by law, upon collection, to a separate, segregated fund, which must be credited to taxpayers in the following year as instructed by the governing body of the political subdivision on whose behalf the millage was levied. An entity submitting a millage rate in excess of that authorized by law shall pay the costs of implementing this subsection or a pro rata share of the costs if more than one entity submits an excessive millage rate.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-43-285(B) (Supp. 2006).Â  While section 12-43-285 clearly would apply to petitionersâ€™ lawsuit if they prevail on the merits, this section goes more to the manner of remedy rather than procedure.Â  
Furthermore, we note that section 12-43-285 was enacted in 2001 and applies to property tax years beginning after December 31, 1999.Â  Therefore, the RPA was already in effect at the time this section became law.Â  It is well settled that the law â€œdoes not favor the implied repeal of statute,â€ and â€œ[s]tatutes dealing with the same subject matter must be reconciled, if possible, so as to render both operative.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 88, 533 S.E.2d 578, 583 (2000) (citing Butler v. Unisun Ins., 323 S.C. 402, 475 S.E.2d 758 (1996)).
Given that the exhaustion of administrative remedy requirement of the RPA covers â€œany case involving the illegal or wrongful collection of taxes,â€ Â§ 12-60-80(A), and section 12-43-285 deals with excessive millage, these two statutes should be reconciled.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, supra. Â Therefore, rather than interpreting section 12-43-285 as displacing the exhaustion requirement of the RPA and replacing that with a right of direct access to the circuit court, we hold the Court of Appeals properly harmonized these two statutes.Â  Put simply, we agree with the Court of Appealsâ€™ observation that â€œ[h]ad the Legislature intended to allow for direct action in circuit court - in contravention of the broadly defined scope of the RPA - it could have expressly provided for such immediate judicial review.â€Â  B & A Dev., 361 S.C. at 460, 605 S.E.2d at 554; see also Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 276, 625 S.E.2d 636, 640 (2006) (where a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, the court has no right to impose another meaning).
Third, petitioners claim that Brackenbrook was unforeseeable and therefore should be applied prospectively.Â  Because the language of the RPA is so plain, we disagree.Â  As noted above, the original language of the Act stated that the RPA applied to â€œany disputed revenue liability.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-20 (2000).Â  Moreover, the RPA expressly provides that the administrative remedies under the Act are exclusive for â€œany case involving the illegal or wrongful collection of taxes.â€ Â Â§ 12-60-80(A). Â 
Additionally, prior to the filing of petitionersâ€™ lawsuit, this Court had interpreted the RPA as establishing â€œadministrative procedures for taxpayers who claim a refund of any state tax.â€Â  Evans v. State, 344 S.C. 60, 65, 543 S.E.2d 547, 549 (2001).Â  In Evans, the Court held that because the class of state retirees was mounting an â€œas appliedâ€ constitutional challenge, the exhaustion of administrative remedies requirement applied.Â  While the Evans case dealt with a state tax issue, rather than a county tax claim, the Brackenbrook decision did not establish any new legal principle, but rather interpreted the plain language of the RPA.Â  
Thus, given the plain language of the statute as well as the case law in effect when petitioners filed their complaint, we reject petitionersâ€™ contention that the Brackenbrook decision regarding the exhaustion doctrine should be prospective.Â  
Finally, petitioners claim that the RPA does not provide a constitutionally adequate, â€œclear and certainâ€ remedy for their claims.Â  See McKesson Corp. v. Div. of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco, 496 U.S. 18 (1990) (where the United States Supreme Court held that due process requires all taxpayers to have a â€œclear and certainâ€ remedy for taxes collected in violation of law).Â  However, we agree with the Court of Appeals that petitioners have not offered any satisfying reason why the RPAâ€™s post-deprivation refund procedures are constitutionally inadequate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 12-60-2560, 12-60-2940; see also National Private Truck Council, Inc. v. Oklahoma Tax Commâ€™n, 515 U.S. 582, 587 (1995) (â€œthe States are afforded great flexibility in satisfying the requirements of due process in the field of taxationâ€).
Petitionersâ€™ more specific argument on this point is that the RPA refund sections envision challenges to valuation of property; because this is an excessive millage case, petitioners contend that the RPA does not provide a remedy.Â  As discussed above, however, the Court in Brackenbrook rejected the idea that the RPA covers only valuation issues.Â  Brackenbrook, 360 S.C. at 398, 602 S.E.2d at 44 (although the RPA contains many procedures for taxpayers to challenge their property tax assessments, relief under the RPA â€œis not limited to these types of protestsâ€).
In sum, we hold the Court of Appeals correctly affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that petitioners are required to exhaust their administrative remedies before proceeding to circuit court.
2.Â  Class Action Status
Petitioners also argue that the Court of Appeals failed â€œto protect absent class membersâ€ by acknowledging, in a footnote, that the RPA was amended in 2003 to expressly disallow class actions.[4]Â  Petitioners further note the following language in the opinion:Â  â€œStyling[5] the suit a class action on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, [petitioners] brought this suit against several governing bodies and officers of the County.â€Â  B & A Dev., 361 S.C. at 455, 605 S.E.2d at 552.Â  More specifically, petitioners contend that because they filed their lawsuit as a putative class action prior to section 12-60-80â€™s amendment, the Court of Appeals erred when it â€œintimatedâ€ that the instant case could not proceed as a class action.Â  
The Court of Appeals, however, did not actually make the ruling which petitioners raise to this Court.Â  It is well settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review. Â See, e.g., Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 529 S.E.2d 543 (2000).Â  In the instant case, the circuit court neither certified a class nor denied class certification.[6]Â  Moreover, class action status was not presented as an issue to the Court of Appeals.Â  Therefore, the issue, on the merits, is unpreserved for our review.Â  Id.
Nonetheless, we agree with petitioners that certain language in the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion could be construed as commenting on the substance of this issue.Â  Consequently, we vacate that portion of the opinion which arguably suggests petitioners cannot maintain this case as a class action.Â  See State v. Dunbar,  356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œAn issue that was not
preserved for review should not be addressed by the Court of Appeals, and the courtâ€™s
opinion should be vacated to the extent it addressed an issue that was not preserved.â€).Â  If and when the class certification issue is argued, the parties can present their arguments and a ruling can be rendered based on the legal authority presented.Â  Only then will the issue become preserved for subsequent appellate review and comment.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, we affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion as modified.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
 BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. MOORE, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.
JUSTICE MOORE:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I adhere to my dissenting opinion in Brackenbrook N. Charleston, LP v. County of Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 602 S.E.2d 39 (2004), and would hold that the Revenue Procedures Act does not apply in an action challenging a countyâ€™s millage rate.Â  Accordingly, I would reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision and remand to the circuit court for a trial on the merits.
TOAL, C.J., concurs.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-10 et seq. (2000 & Supp. 2006).
[2]Â  Section 12-60-2560, states as follows in pertinent part:

Â (A) Subject to the limitations in Section 12-60-1750, and within the time limitation of Section 12-54-85(F), a property taxpayer may seek a refund of real property taxes assessed by the county assessor and paid, other than taxes paid on property the taxpayer claims is exempt, by filing a claim for refund with the county assessor who made the property tax assessment for the property for which the tax refund is sought.Â  The assessor, upon receipt of a claim for refund, shall immediately notify the county treasurer and the county auditor for the county from which the refund is sought. Â The majority of these three officials shall determine the taxpayerâ€™s refund, if any, and shall notify the taxpayer in writing of their decision.
(B) Within thirty days after the decision is mailed to the taxpayer on the claim for refund, a property taxpayer may appeal the decision to the county board of assessment appeals. â€¦
(C) Within thirty days after the boardâ€™s decision is mailed to the taxpayer, a property taxpayer or county assessor may appeal the decision issued by the board by requesting a contested case hearing before the Administrative Law Judge Division.â€¦Â  If a taxpayer requests a contested case hearing before the Administrative Law Judge Division without exhausting his prehearing remedyâ€¦, the Administrative Law Judge shall dismiss the action without prejudice.

[3] SectionÂ  12-60-2940, entitled â€œClaim for refund of personal property tax; request for contested case hearing following denial of claim.â€ states the following, in relevant part:

(A)    Subject to the limitations in Section 12-60-1750, and within the time limitation of Section 12-54-85(F), a property taxpayer may seek a refund of property taxes assessed by the county auditor and paid, other than taxes paid on property the taxpayer claims is exempt unless the exemption is the homestead exemption, by filing a claim for refund with the county auditor who made the personal property tax assessment on the property for which the tax refund is sought. The auditor upon receipt of a claim for refund shall immediately notify the county treasurer and county assessor. A majority of these three officials shall determine the taxpayer's refund, if any, and shall notify the taxpayer in writing of their decision.
(B)    A taxpayer may appeal the decision by requesting a contested case hearing before the Administrative Law Judge Division in accordance with its rules within thirty days of the written denial of the claim for refund.
(C)    If a taxpayer requests a contested case hearing before the Administrative Law Judge Division without exhausting his prehearing remedy because he failed to file a claim for refund, the Administrative Law Judge shall dismiss the action without prejudice.

[4] B & A Dev., 361 S.C. at 457 n.2, 605 S.E.2d at 553 n.2 (â€œWe also note that recent amendments to Â§ 12-60-80 provide that â€œa claim or action for the refund of taxes may not be brought as a class action in the Administrative Law Judge Division or any court of law in this State....â€ Â§ 12-60-80(C) (Act No. 69, 2003 S.C. Acts 744)).Â  
[5] Based on their briefs, we are assuming petitioners object to the use of the verb â€œstyle.â€
[6]  Â This is in contrast to the situation in Brackenbrook where the circuit court had already certified the class.Â  After this Court concluded that the circuit court should have dismissed the action for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, we directed Charleston County to give notice to all class members of their right to seek an administrative refund.Â  Brackenbrook, however, is factually distinct from this case.Â  Here, no judge has yet addressed the issue of class certification.

title: Williams v. SCDC
description: This case determines that inmates participating in a prison industries program have no cause of action under the Payment of Wages Act.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Darrell Williams, Class Representative, et al.,
Appellants,
v.
South Carolina Department of Corrections and Williams Technologies, Inc.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26274
Heard December 5, 2006 - Filed February 26, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Douglas H. Westbrook, of Charleston, for appellants.
Lake E. Summers, of Malone, Thompson & Summers, LLC, of Columbia, for respondent South Carolina Department of Corrections.
Marc A. Manos and Manton M. Grier, Jr., both of Nexsen Pruet, LLC, of Columbia, for respondent Williams Technologies, Inc.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE: Â This class action was commenced on behalf of inmates in custody of respondent South Carolina Department of Corrections (DOC).Â  These inmates participated in a prison industry program operated pursuant to DOCâ€™s contract with respondent Williams Technologies, Inc. (WTI).Â  Appellants (Inmates) claim they were underpaid for their labor and seek â€œlost wages.â€Â  The trial judge dismissed Inmatesâ€™ complaint with prejudice based on our decision in Adkins v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 360 S.C. 413, 602 S.E.2d 51 (2004).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In Adkins, we considered a suit by inmates against DOC as the sole defendant.Â  The suit alleged a violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-430(D) (Supp. 2005) which provides that â€œno inmate participating in [a prison industries] program may earn less than the prevailing wage for work of similar nature in the private sector.â€Â  We held there is no private cause of action for a violation of this statute.[1]
Inmates here alleged a cause of action under the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, S.C. Code Â§ 41-10-20 et seq. (Supp. 2005) claiming lost wages because they were not paid the â€œprevailing wageâ€ as specified in Â§ 24-3-430(D).[2]Â Â  They claim the trial judge should not have dismissed this cause of action against WTI.[3]
ISSUE

Do inmates have a cause of action under the Payment of Wages Act?

DISCUSSION
The Payment of Wages Act requires that every employer â€œnotify each employee in writing at the time of hiring of the normal hours and wages agreed upon, the time and place of payment, and the deductions which will be made. . . .â€Â  Â§ 41-10-30.Â  Every employer shall pay wages due at the time and place designated by this notice.Â  Â§ 41-10-40(D).Â  There is no provision regarding the payment of a statutorily required wage.
Whether a private industry sponsor and the inmates in a prison industries program have an employer-employee relationship for purposes of the Payment of Wages Act is a novel issue.Â  Inmates ask us to find such a relationship based on the test for employment set out in Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 400 S.E.2d 781 (1991).Â  This test includes four factors:Â  (1) the right to, or exercise of, control; (2) method of payment; (3) furnishing of equipment; and (4) right to fire.Â  Inmates point to provisions in the contract between DOC and WTI that indicate WTIâ€™s right to control inmate workers.Â  For instance, the contract provides that WTI provides worker training and supervisory staff to oversee work product quality, and WTI furnishes the equipment upon which the work is performed.Â  Although DOC screens and selects the inmates who will participate, WTI â€œreserves the right to have [DOC] remove and replace inmate workers based on job performance.â€Â  Inmates contend the contract provisions stating that inmates are not to be considered employees of WTI do not control.
We find the Felts four-part test is not determinative of employer status in the context of the Payment of Wages Act.Â  This Act, by its very title, is concerned specifically with the payment of wages and is directed to the entity responsible for such payment.Â  See Williams v. Grimes Aerospace Co., 988 F. Supp. 925, n.13 (D.S.C. 1997) (holding that corporation for whom work was performed was not liable under South Carolina Payment of Wages Act where temporary agency â€œhandled all payment of wagesâ€).Â  
Here, the payment of inmate wages is exclusively within the control of DOC and not WTI.Â  The contract provides that WTI will pay DOC a flat rate of $4.00 per hour per inmate and that DOC is responsible to pay inmate workers and handle payroll deductions.Â  Of even greater significance is the fact that the legislature has specifically mandated how inmate wages for prison industry labor are to be handled.Â  Section 24-3-40 (Supp. 2005) provides:

Disposition of wages of prisoner allowed to work at paid employment.
(A) Unless otherwise provided by law, the employer of a prisoner authorized to work at paid employment . . . in a prison industry program provided under Article 3 of this chapter shall pay the prisonerâ€™s wages directly to the Department of Corrections.

(emphasis added).Â  This section also includes specific deductions from inmate wages that are to be made by the Director of DOC, including restitution to victims, payment to the State Office of Victim Assistance, child support, and state and federal taxes.Â  Clearly, by contract and by statute, DOC is the only entity responsible for the payment of inmate wages.Â  
Other state courts have held for purposes of wage statutes that inmates compensated by the prison are not the employees of prison industry sponsors.Â  See Manville v. Bd. of Governors of Wayne State Univ., 272 N.W.2d 162 (Mich. App. 1978) (rate of compensation for prison labor determined under state Correctional Industries Act, not Minimum Wage Law where Department of Corrections unilaterally set wage scale and work hours); Prieur v. D.C.I. Plasma Center of Nevada, Inc., 726 P.2d 1372 (Nev. 1986) (prison laborer barred from pursuing claim against prison industry sponsor under state wage and hour law where Department of Prisons determined rate and method of compensation).Â  Federal courts have come to the same result under the Federal Labor Standards Act.Â  E.g., Henthorn v. Depâ€™t of Navy, 29 F.3d 682 (D.C. Cir. 1994); Harker v. State Use Indus., 990 F.2d 131 (4th Cir. 1993); Gilbreath v. Cutter Biological, Inc., 931 F.2d 1320 (9th Cir. 1991); George v. SC Data Center, Inc., 884 F.Supp. 329 (W.D. Wis. 1995).Â  
In conclusion, Inmates cannot maintain an action against WTI under the Payment of Wages Act since WTI is not the entity responsible for paying their wages. Â We affirm Inmatesâ€™ remaining issues under Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.Â  See Adkins, supra (prevailing wage statute was not enacted for the special benefit of inmates but was intended to prevent unfair competition and aid the public in general).Â  
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  As I explained in my concurring opinion in Adkins v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 360 S.C. 413, 602 S.E.2d 51 (2004), I would hold that the inmatesâ€™ remedy is found in the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10, et seq. (Supp. 2005).Â  
To hold that the payment of wages is exclusively within the control of the DOC ignores the language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-40 (Supp. 2005).Â  That statute provides â€œthe employer of a prisoner authorized to workâ€¦.in a prison industry programâ€¦.shall pay the prisonerâ€™s wages directly to the Department of Correctionsâ€ and then requires the DOC to distribute those wages to inmates on behalf of the employer.Â  Thus, the ultimate responsibility for paying wages falls on the prison industry sponsor, while the DOC merely acts as a conduit for payment to the inmates.
Under the Payment of Wages Act, â€œEmployerâ€ is defined as â€œevery person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, receiver, or other officer of a court of this State, the State or any political subdivision thereof, and any agent or officer of the above classes employing any person in this State.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-10(1).Â  In my opinion, this definition includes both the employer, WTI, and its agent, the DOC.Â  Accordingly, I would hold that both WTI and the DOC are subject to the inmatesâ€™ claims made pursuant to the Payment of Wages Act. 

[1]In the companion case of Wicker v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 360 S.C. 421, 602 S.E.2d 56 (2004), we further held that inmates may not be deprived of this property interest without due process; accordingly, inmates were directed to file grievances if they wished to protest DOCâ€™s failure to pay a prevailing wage.
[2]Inmates concede that DOC was authorized to negotiate wages for inmate labor at less than the prevailing wage pursuant to budget provisos passed by the General Assembly for fiscal years 2001-2002 and 2002-2003.Â  There are similar provisions in each budget passed to the present.
[3]In Adkins, we noted Â§ 24-3-430(F) provides that an inmate is not considered an â€œemployeeâ€ of the State and therefore no cause of action could be maintained against DOC under the Payment of Wages Act.Â  360 S.C. at 420, n.7, 602 S.E.2d at 55, n.7.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Appellant,
v.
First Carolina Corporation of S.C., Landowner, and Edisto Farm Credit,
ACA, Mortgagee, Other Condemnee(s) of whom First Carolina Corporation of S.C. is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Jasper County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26275
Heard January 3, 2007 - Filed February 27, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
B. Michael Brackett, of Moses Koon & Brackett, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Daniel E. Henderson, of Peters Murdaugh Parker Eltzroth & Detrick, of Ridgeland, and Thomas A. Holloway, of Harvey & Battey, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This case arises out of a condemnation action by the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) and was certified for review from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  First Carolina Corporation of South Carolina (First Carolina) initiated a suit to determine the value of a piece of condemned property.Â  The trial court submitted the case to the jury with instructions for the jury to utilize a special verdict form provided by the court.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of First Carolina and awarded compensation for the land taken and special damages to the remaining property.Â  SCDOT appealed.Â  We affirm.
Factual / Procedural Background
SCDOT condemned approximately eight (8) acres of land belonging to First Carolina.Â  The condemned property was part of a larger, four hundred (400) acre tract of land.Â  First Carolina initiated an action to determine the amount of compensation owed by SCDOT for the condemnation of First Carolinaâ€™s property.Â  
During trial, First Carolina argued that it should be compensated based on the value of land taken plus any special damages to the remaining property.Â  SCDOT argued that First Carolinaâ€™s method inflated the value of the condemned property.Â  Instead, SCDOT advocated for the use of the â€œbefore and afterâ€ appraisal methodology.Â  
First Carolina submitted a special verdict form to the court.Â  After the trial court announced its intention to utilize a modified version of the special verdict form, SCDOT indicated that it would prefer a general verdict form.Â  The trial court denied SCDOTâ€™s request to use a general verdict form.Â  
The modified special verdict form utilized by the court asked the jury to 1) unanimously determine just compensation for the land taken, 2) unanimously determine whether the taking caused any special damage to the remaining property, and 3) determine the amount of the special damages, if any. 
Following the charge to the jury, but before the court delivered the trial exhibits and special verdict form to the jury, SCDOT again objected to the use of the special verdict form on the basis that it â€œemphasizes damages by its bifurcated nature and the Department [didnâ€™t] believe that the landowner ha[d] proven its damages to the standards required by the law.â€Â  The trial court overruled SCDOTâ€™s objection and submitted the form to the jury on the basis that the form would simplify an appellate review of the verdict.Â  The jury returned a verdict of $1,990,975.00, of which $640,300.00 was for the land acquired and $1,350,675.00 for the damage to the remaining property.Â  
SCDOT filed several post-trial motions, including a request for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict based upon the argument that the verdict form was unduly suggestive of the appraisal method advocated by First Carolina.Â  The trial court denied the motion and this appeal followed.Â  
SCDOT appeals raising the following issues for review:

  
    
      I.  
       Did the trial court err in utilizing a special verdict form because the nature of the case, the facts, or the evidence did not warrant a special verdict?
        
        
    
    
      II. 
       Was the special verdict form submitted by the trial court unduly suggestive or misleading as to the appraisal method to be used by the jury in calculating just compensation?[1] 
    
  

Standard of Review
The determination of whether a special verdict should be submitted to the jury is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and an appellate court will only reverse upon a finding of an abuse of that discretion. Smoak v. Liebherr-America, Inc., 281 S.C. 420, 421, 315 S.E.2d 116, 118 (1984).Â Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support. Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005).
Law / Analysis
I.  Use of Special Verdict Form
SCDOT argues that the trial court erred in utilizing a special verdict form because the nature of the case, the facts, and the evidence did not warrant a special verdict.Â  We disagree.Â  
The trial judge has the discretion to determine how a case is submitted to the jury.Â  Smoak, 281 S.C. at 421, 315 S.E.2d at 118.Â Â  Rule 49(a), SCRCP, provides in part:

The court may require a jury to return only a special verdict in the form of a special written finding upon each issue of fact. In that event the court may submit to the jury written questions susceptible of categorical or other brief answer or may submit written forms of the several special findings which might properly be made under the pleadings and evidence; or it may use such other method of submitting the issues and requiring the written findings thereon as it deems most appropriate.

SCDOT does not dispute the discretionary nature of this decision in its brief.Â  Furthermore, SCDOT does not argue that the trial court abused its discretion by submitting the special verdict form to the jury.Â  The only arguments SCDOT propounds are that the verdict form is misleading and that the use of a general verdict form would have simplified the appeals process.Â  
We find that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in utilizing a special verdict form.Â  Rule 49, SCRCP, clearly allows the court to use special verdicts in its discretion.Â  Even if a general verdict was more practical given the circumstances of this case, this fact alone does not amount to an abuse of discretion.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court did not err in utilizing a special verdict form in this case.
II.  Prejudicial Effect of the Special Verdict Form 
SCDOT argues that the special verdict form submitted by the trial court was unduly suggestive or misleading as to the appraisal method to be used by the jury in calculating just compensation.Â  We disagree.
At the outset we must address the trial courtâ€™s ruling that SCDOT waived its objection to the special verdict form.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
It is well settled that an issue may not be raised for the first time in a post-trial motion.Â  McGee v. Bruce Hosp. Syst., 321 S.C. 340, 347, 468 S.E.2d 633, 637 (1996).Â Â  Further, it is a litigantâ€™s duty to bring to the courtâ€™s attention any perceived error, and the failure to do so amounts to a waiver of the alleged error.Â  Parks v. Morris Homes Corp., 245 S.C. 461, 471, 141 S.E.2d 129, 134 (1965).Â  Additionally, â€œ[i]t is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€ Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998). â€œThere are four basic requirements to preserving issues at trial for appellate review. The issue must have been (1) raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, (2) raised by the appellant, (3) raised in a timely manner, and (4) raised to the trial court with sufficient specificity.â€ Jean Hoefer Toal et al., Appellate Practice in South Carolina 57 (2d ed. 2002).
During trial, the court announced its intention to use a special verdict form and asked if either party objected to the use of the form.Â  SCDOT stated that â€œwe would just prefer the first verdict form.â€Â  The court denied the request finding the special verdict form appropriate and in the interest of â€œjudicial economy and appellate court economy.â€Â  The court then asked if either party wished to include more instructions regarding the use of the form, and SCDOT replied, â€œI understand and, your honor, if you are going to use this form then thatâ€™s fine, either way.â€Â  After the court charged the jury, but before the court gave the jury the verdict form, SCDOT again objected to the use of the verdict form stating â€œthe Department objects to the verdict form [sic] it emphasizes damages by its bifurcated nature and the Department doesnâ€™t believe that the landowner has proven its damages to the standards required by the law in this case.â€Â  The court overruled SCDOTâ€™s objection.
SCDOT filed a motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict asserting that the verdict form was unduly suggestive.Â  The trial court found that SCDOT did not object to the use of the verdict form on that basis, and therefore, the court found that the objection was waived.Â  SCDOT argues that although it did not use those exact words, it nonetheless objected to the use of the special verdict form on the basis that it emphasized the appraisal method advocated by First Carolina.
We hold that SCDOT made a timely objection to the use of the special verdict form.Â  Although SCDOT did not phrase its objection in the exact terms used in the issues on appeal, SCDOTâ€™s objection on the basis that the verdict form â€œemphasizes damages by its bifurcated natureâ€ provided a meaningful objection with sufficient specificity to allow the trial court to rule on the issue.Â  State v. Russell, 345 S.C. 128, 134, 546 S.E.2d 202, 204 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding that a party need not use the exact name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve an argument, but it must be clear that the argument has been presented on that ground).Â  In fact, the trial court denied the motion finding that the form did not emphasize damages because the jury could choose to calculate damages using SCDOTâ€™s proposed method and fill in only the first question.Â  Further, SCDOTâ€™s initial objection and discussion with the trial court regarding the use of the special verdict form was not a concession to the use of the form.Â  The record reflects that SCDOTâ€™s statement, â€œI understand and, your honor, if you are going to use this form then thatâ€™s fine, either way,â€ was simply a response to the courtâ€™s question concerning any requests for additional instructions to the jury on the form.Â  
Turning to the merits, a special verdict question may be so defective in its formulation that its submission results in a prejudicial effect which constitutes reversible error.Â  9A Wright & Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure, Civil 2d Â§ 2508, p.193.Â  In evaluating the prejudicial effect of a defective special verdict question or special interrogatory, the court must consider the question or interrogatory along with the instructions given to the jury.Â  Fortune v. Gibson, 304 S.C. 279, 282, 403 S.E.2d 674, 675 (Ct. App. 1991) (finding that special interrogatories and instructions must be considered together).Â  The prejudicial effect of a defective verdict form may be cured where the trial court provides clear and cogent jury instructions.Â 
See State v. Covert, 368 S.C. 188, 214, 628 S.E.2d 482, __ (Ct. App. 2006); State v. Myers, 344 S.C. 532, 536, 544 S.E.2d 851, 853 (Ct. App. 2001).[2] Â Â 
The special verdict form submitted to the jury by the court asked three questions: [3] Â Â 

1) We, the jury, unanimously find just compensation for the landowner for the land actually taken by the Department of Transportation to be __________________.
2) Do you, the jury, unanimously find any special damages to the remaining property of the landowner that are a direct and proximate result of the taking? ___ No.Â  If No is chosen, end deliberations and sign verdict form.Â  ___ Yes.Â  If Yes is chosen, go to Question 3.
3) We, the jury, unanimously find special damages to the remaining property of the landowner in the amount of _______________.

During the jury charge, the trial court explained to the jury that it could find just compensation using either of the two methods presented during trial.Â  The court went on to explain fully both the â€œbefore and afterâ€ method of calculation, and also the appraisal method which requires a finding of the value of land taken plus damage to the remaining property.Â  At the end of the jury charge, the court explained the use of the verdict form.Â Â Â  The court further explained that the jury was not required to find any compensation under Question 3, but if it did find compensation under Question 3, that amount would be in addition to the compensation found in Question 1.Â  
Reading the verdict form in conjunction with the jury instructions, we find that any possible confusion or misapprehension caused by the verdict form was remedied by the instructions from the court.Â  The form did not misstate the law or restrict the juryâ€™s finding to one method of calculation. Â Furthermore, although SCDOT argues that the more prudent choice would have been to use a general verdict form, SCDOT presented no evidence that the use of the special verdict form bent the will of the jury or prejudiced SCDOT in any way.Â  
Accordingly, the special verdict form utilized by the trial court was not unduly suggestive or misleading, and did not prejudice SCDOT.Â  Additionally, any perceived defect in the form was cured by the trial courtâ€™s instructions as to the law and use of the form.
Conclusion
For the forgoing reasons, we affirm.
 MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justices James W. Johnson, Jr., and L. Casey Manning, concur.

[1] In the interest of clarity, we have reorganized and combined issues II through VII presented by SCDOT for this Courtâ€™s review.
[2] Rule 49, SCRCP, is identical to the federal rule.Â  Under federal case law, it is improper to use a special verdict form which is likely to confuse or mislead the jury.Â  However, such error may be corrected by clear instructions to the jury.Â  See Sanghvi v. City of Claremont, 328 F.3d 532, 541-42 (9th Cir. 2003); Greenleaf v. Garlock, Inc., 174 F.3d 352, 363 (3rd Cir. 1999); Â Horstmyer v. Black & Decker, Inc., 151 F.3d 765, 771-72 (8th Cir. 1998); Umpleby v. Potter & Brumfield, Inc., 69 F.3d 209, 214 (7th Cir. 1995); and Cutlass Productions, Inc. v. Bregman, 682 F.2d 323, 327 (2nd Cir. 1982).Â Â Â  
[3] The special verdict form used by the trial court closely resembles the measure of just compensation as required in the Eminent Domain Procedure Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-370 (2005) (providing that â€œin determining just compensation, only the value of the property to be taken, any diminution in the value of the landownerâ€™s remaining property, and any benefits as provided in Â§ 28-2-360 may be consideredâ€).

description: This case deals with what constitutes proper notice under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003), the â€œrecidivist statute.â€  Reversing the court of appeals, the Court held that actual notice is sufficient to comply with the statuteâ€™s notice requirement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Willie James, Respondent,
v.
The State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Florence County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Post Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No. 26276
Submitted January 18, 2007 - Filed February 27, 2007Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney GeneralÂ  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Sabrina C. Todd, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this PCR case, the court of appeals held that the fact that Respondent Willie James (â€œRespondentâ€) had actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek a sentence of life without the possibility of parole under South Carolinaâ€™s recidivist statute did not satisfy the Codeâ€™s requirement that both Respondent and his counsel receive written notice of the Stateâ€™s intention prior to Respondentâ€™s trial.Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals held that Respondentâ€™s trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object that Respondent did not receive the required written notification.Â  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background
Respondent was convicted of armed robbery in April 1998.Â  Because Respondentâ€™s criminal record included a previous conviction for armed robbery, Respondent was eligible to be sentenced under South Carolinaâ€™s â€œtwo strikes/three strikesâ€ recidivist statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003).Â  Pursuant to the statute, the trial court sentenced Respondent to imprisonment for life without the possibility of parole (â€œLWOPâ€), and this Court upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision on direct appeal.Â  State v. James, Op. No. 2000-MO-101 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July 19, 2000).
In 2001, Respondent filed a petition for post-conviction relief.Â  As one of several grounds raised in his petition, Respondent alleged that his trial counsel was ineffective in not objecting to Respondentâ€™s sentence on the basis of the Stateâ€™s failure to provide Respondent with written notice of its intention to seek LWOP as required by Â§ 17-25-45(H).
The PCR court denied Respondent relief and offered two principal bases for its decision.Â  First, the court found that both Respondent and his trial counsel were aware of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek LWOP well in advance of Respondentâ€™s trial.Â  In light of this Courtâ€™s precedent providing that Â§ 17-25-45(H) requires only actual notice, see State v. Washington, 338 S.C. 392, 526 S.E.2d 709 (2000), the PCR court concluded that the statute had not been violated.Â  The court distinguished the court of appeals case State v. Johnson, 347 S.C. 67, 552 S.E.2d 339 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding that Â§ 17-25-45(H)â€™s written notice requirement is mandatory), on the grounds that in the instant case, it was Respondent, and not trial counsel, who did not receive written notification.Â  As a second basis for its decision, the PCR court found that providing written notice to Respondentâ€™s trial counsel, who was Respondentâ€™s agent for service of official documents, would be sufficient to comply with a requirement that written notice be provided to Respondent.Â  
The court of appeals reversed the PCR courtâ€™s decision.Â  Relying directly on its opinion in Johnson, the court held that Â§ 17-25-45(H) was clear and unambiguous in its requirement that both a defendant and his counsel be served with written notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek an LWOP sentence prior to trial.Â  James v. State, 368 S.C. 323, 325, 628 S.E.2d 892, 893 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The court held that trial counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness given his failure to object to the Stateâ€™s clear non-compliance with the statute, and the court found that this deficiency prejudiced Respondent because Respondent was â€œsentenced to [LWOP] in violation of the statute.â€Â  Id. at 325-26, 628 S.E.2d at 894.
After the court of appeals remitted the case, we ordered the court of appeals to recall the remittitur and announced our intention to grant a writ of certiorari.Â  The State presents the following issue for review:

Did the court of appeals err in finding that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to Respondentâ€™s sentence where Respondent did not receive written notice that the State would be seeking a sentence of life without the possibility of parole?

Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings and conclusions.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995)).Â  A PCR courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on review if there is any evidence of probative value supporting them.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).
To establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must establish both that counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness and that but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability that the result of the trial would have been different.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984).Â Â  
Law/Analysis
The State argues that Respondentâ€™s trial counsel was not ineffective for failing to object that Respondent had not been provided with written notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek an LWOP sentence prior to trial.Â  We agree.
As an initial matter, the posture in which the issue of Respondentâ€™s receipt of notice arose at trial is revealing.Â  During the preliminary motions phase immediately preceding Respondentâ€™s trial, the parties engaged in a discussion with the trial court about the issue of notice.Â  At the beginning of this colloquy, both Respondent and Respondentâ€™s counsel indicated that each was aware that Respondent was facing the possibility of an LWOP sentence. Â The court then inquired as to whether the solicitor had given written notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek such a sentence, and the solicitor indicated that although a copy of the notice was not filed with the clerkâ€™s office, he had provided written notice to Respondentâ€™s counsel approximately six months prior to trial.Â  Respondentâ€™s counsel then indicated that the defense â€œhad noticeâ€ and had â€œknown about this for months.â€Â  The issue of notice was not raised again until the sentencing phase of Respondentâ€™s trial, and during the sentencing proceeding, the solicitor provided the court with a copy of the written notice he had previously given to Respondentâ€™s counsel.Â  The court indicated that the parties had agreed that the defense was on notice as to the potential sentence in the case and that â€œnotice was adequate.â€
As these facts demonstrate, the issue of notice arose first at the pre-trial stage and the discussion concluded when Respondentâ€™s counsel stipulated that the defense had received adequate notice.Â  Given this scenario, the proper interpretation of Respondentâ€™s PCR claim is that counsel should have objected that Respondent had not been provided with written notice as required by the statute instead of stipulating that notice was adequate.Â  Respondentâ€™s claim may not be interpreted as an assertion that his counsel should have stipulated as he did during the pre-trial phase and then raised this issue again at sentencing.Â  See Erickson v. Jones Street Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 475-76, 629 S.E.2d 653, 670 (2006) (providing that generally, a party may not complain about an error induced by his own conduct).
This clarification is important because assuming that Respondentâ€™s counsel was deficient for failing to object to the alleged non-compliance with the statute, Respondent cannot demonstrate that this deficiency resulted in any prejudice.Â  As this Courtâ€™s precedent provides, jeopardy does not attach in a jury trial until the jury is sworn and impaneled.Â  State v. Rountree, 127 S.C. 261, 262, 121 S.E. 205, 205 (1924).Â  In the instant case, counselâ€™s stipulation occurred pre-trial and before the jury was sworn.Â  Thus, assuming that competent counsel would have objected based on the lack of written notice instead of stipulating that notice was adequate, upon hearing such an objection, the solicitor could simply have dismissed the indictment, re-indicted Respondent, provided Respondent with written notice, and proceeded to seek an LWOP sentence.Â  Furthermore, leaving jeopardy analysis aside, it would have been entirely proper for the solicitor, upon hearing counselâ€™s objection, to have concluded with the pre-trial motions in the case and postponed Respondentâ€™s trial to allow the solicitor to provide Respondent with written notice.Â  Either of these procedures would have resulted in Respondent receiving an LWOP sentence despite the objection that Respondent contends trial counsel should have offered.
The court of appeals was mistaken in characterizing the prejudice in this case as Respondent being sentenced in violation of the statute.Â  Instead, the proper characterization of any error is that Respondent agreed to proceed immediately to trial despite the violation of the statute.Â  Instructively, there is no authority that would prevent the State, should this Court grant Respondentâ€™s request for a new trial, from seeking an LWOP sentence under the recidivist statute on remand.[1]
Respondent cannot demonstrate that but for trial counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability the result of the trial would have been different.Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals erred in determining that Respondent received ineffective assistance from his trial counsel. [2]Â  
The Stateâ€™s argument in favor of reversal goes along different lines.[3]Â Â  Specifically, the State argues that the court of appeals erred in reversing Respondentâ€™s sentence because Â§ 17-25-45(H) requires only actual notice.Â  Again, we agree.
The recidivist statuteâ€™s notice provision, Â§ 17-25-45(H), provides:

Where the solicitor is required to seek or determines to seek sentencing of a defendant under this section, written notice must be given by the solicitor to the defendant and the defendantâ€™s counsel not less than ten days before trial.

Our decision in State v. Washington controls the resolution of this issue.Â  That case involved a prosecution for first degree burglary, and although the solicitor gave the defendant written notice that he would be seeking a sentence under the recidivist statute, due to errors in the original indictment, the solicitor later re-indicted the defendant.Â  338 S.C. at 398, 526 S.E.2d at 711-12.Â  After the re-indictment, the solicitor did not send a second notice to the defendant.Â  Id. at 398, 526 S.E.2d at 712.
We held that the failure to send a second notice to the defendant did not prevent the imposition of an LWOP sentence under the recidivist statute.Â  After recounting the fact that South Carolina law has historically not required that a defendant be informed if he is going to be punished more severely on the basis of his previous convictions, we stated â€œ[t]his Court has found that under such notice statutes, the law only requires actual notice.â€Â  Id. at 399, 526 S.E.2d at 712.Â  Ultimately, this Court concluded that since the defendant â€œhad actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intent, a second notice following re-indictment was unnecessary.â€Â  Id.
Despite Washingtonâ€™s clear pronouncement, the court of appeals reached a contrary interpretation of Â§ 17-25-45(H) in State v. Johnson, on which the court based its decision in the instant case.Â  In Johnson, the court of appeals held:

By its words in the recidivist statute, the General Assembly has mandated that the solicitor â€œmustâ€ notify the defendant and the defendantâ€™s counsel in writing if the solicitor intends to seek a life sentence without the possibility of parole. . . . In our view, actual notice under section 17-25-45(H) is insufficient unless and until the General Assembly decides otherwise and amends the statute itself.

347 S.C. at 70, 552 S.E.2d at 340.Â  The court of appeals distinguished Washington on the grounds that, in that case, the defendant had received written notice that the solicitor was seeking to invoke the recidivist statute, albeit before the original indictment was dismissed.Â  Johnson, 347 S.C. at 71, 552 S.E.2d at 341.Â  The court opined that Washington
was decided on the basis that the prior written notice sufficiently satisfied the statuteâ€™s written notice requirement.Â  Id.Â  
The fact that we declined to grant a writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision in Johnson is not an impediment to our reviewing the merits of that decision now.Â  Although there are subtle distinctions in the facts presented in Washington and Johnson, any attempt to make a meaningful distinction between the cases does not withstand serious scrutiny.[4]Â  Thus, we are faced with a situation in which this Court has made a clear pronouncement on an issue, and the court of appeals has subsequently strayed from adhering to that pronouncement.Â  Either the rule we announced in Washington
requires revision, or the rule requires restating.
Nothing about our holding in Washington was equivocal, and we can discern no sufficient rationale for adopting a rule contrary to the one we there advanced. Â The purpose of Â§ 17-25-45(H) is to assure that a defendant and his counsel have actual notice that the State is seeking a sentence under the recidivist statute at least ten days prior to trial.Â  Accordingly, so long as the defendant and his counsel, at least ten days prior to trial, possess actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek a sentence under South Carolinaâ€™s recidivist statute, the statute has been satisfied.Â  As the court of appealsâ€™ decision in State v. Johnson is inconsistent with this pronouncement, it is overruled.[5]
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Indeed, if Respondent was charged with armed robbery on remand, a â€œmost serious offenseâ€ as defined in Â§ 17-25-45(C), the solicitor would, in fact, be required to seek an LWOP sentence under the recidivist statute. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(G) (2003).Â  Similarly, if Respondent was again found guilty, the trial court would have no choice but to sentence Respondent to LWOP.
[2] Though we express no opinion on how our analysis would differ in the face of such a claim, we note that Respondent has not asserted that receiving written notice would have affected the merits of the defense he presented at trial.
[3] Although the State has not presented the prejudice analysis we have outlined, our appellate rules provide that we may affirm a decision upon any grounds appearing in the record.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR.
[4] While the scenario in Washington dealt with the defendantâ€™s receipt of written notice in a re-indictment situation, the issue of notification in Johnson dealt with the defendantâ€™s attorney, who had not provided with written notice at any time.Â  In light of the actual holdings in these cases, however, this distinction is insignificant.
[5] As a practical matter, the most effective way of assuring that both defendant and counsel receive actual notice in the required time frame is to provide them notice in writing.Â  Though this seems a simple task, the frequency with which this issue has appeared in our jurisprudence reveals that it is overlooked with surprising regularity.Â  This problem ought to be easily identifiable and preventable.
Finally, there is ample evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s conclusion that both Respondent and his counsel had actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intentions.Â  Trial counsel testified at the PCR hearing that he had notice several months prior to Respondentâ€™s trial, and Respondent indicated on several occasions, including months in advance of trial, that he knew he was facing an LWOP sentence under â€œthe habitual criminal act.â€

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Dwayne Elliott Johnson, Respondent,
v.
The South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services,
Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26277
Heard January 18, 2007 - Filed February 27, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Assistant Chief Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, and Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, the trial court held that the absence of a favorable recommendation from a probation officer did not deprive the court of subject matter jurisdiction to grant early termination of a personâ€™s probation.Â  Relying on technical defects in the appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.Â  This Court granted the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, & Pardon Servicesâ€™ (â€œthe Departmentâ€™sâ€) petition for a writ of certiorari, and we now affirm.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
This case arises out of Dwayne Elliott Johnsonâ€™s (â€œJohnsonâ€™sâ€) successful pro se motion to have his probation terminated early.Â  In April 1992, Johnson was convicted of first degree burglary and grand larceny.Â  Although Johnson received a sentence of twenty-five years imprisonment, the trial court suspended the sentence conditioned upon the service of eighteen years imprisonment and five years probation for the burglary conviction, and ten years imprisonment for the grand larceny conviction.Â  Johnson was released from prison in 2000 and began probation in April 2001.
Approximately one year after beginning his probation, Johnson filed a pro se motion asking the court to terminate his probation early.Â  At a hearing on the motion, the Department argued that the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to consider Johnsonâ€™s request because the request was not accompanied by a recommendation from the agent in charge of the responsible county probation office in support of early termination.
The trial court held that subject matter jurisdiction over the issue of early termination of probation was not contingent upon the presence of a recommendation from the Department.Â  After hearing testimony from witnesses offered by Johnson and the Department,[1] the trial court terminated Johnsonâ€™s probation effective April 2003; exactly two years after Johnson began serving his probation sentence and approximately three years early.Â  The Department appealed.
The court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision in an unpublished opinion.Â  See Johnson v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole, & Pardon Serv., Op. No. 04-UP-430 (S.C. Ct. App. filed July 9, 2004).Â  The court noted that the Department failed to include Johnsonâ€™s original pro se motion and the trial courtâ€™s final order in the record on appeal, and also that the Department failed to place the documents in the record in the proper order.Â  Id.Â  The court relied on the fact that, as the appellant, the Department had the burden of presenting an adequate record on appeal.Â  Id.Â  The court of appeals thus declined to address the merits of the Departmentâ€™s arguments.
The Department unsuccessfully petitioned the court of appeals to allow the Department to supplement the record on appeal and to grant rehearing in the matter, and this Court granted the Departmentâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari.Â  The Department presents the following issue for review:

Did the court of appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision based upon the Departmentâ€™s failure to present an adequate record on appeal?

Law/Analysis
The Department argues that the court of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision based upon the Departmentâ€™s failure to present an adequate record on appeal.Â  We disagree.
Ordinarily, no point will be considered which does not appear in the record on appeal.Â  Rule 210(h), SCACR.Â  Because court rules require the appealing party to prepare the record on appeal, see Rule 210(a), SCACR, South Carolina courts have traditionally held the appealing party accountable for failing to present the court with an adequate record on appeal for review.
For example, the case of Polson v. Burr arose out of an automobile collision involving three vehicles, and the case originated when the driver of one of the vehicles sued the driver of the second vehicle.Â  235 S.C. 216, 217-18, 110 S.E.2d 855, 856 (1959).Â  On appeal, the driver of the second vehicle argued that the trial court erred in denying his motion to join both the driver and the owner of the third vehicle as necessary parties to the action.Â  Id. at 217, 110 S.E.2d at 856.Â  In dismissing the appeal, this Court stated:

The record states that the Court below refused this motion, although for some unexplained reason the order is not included in the record.Â  . . . [T]he appeal here is not in such shape as to allow us to properly consider the merits.Â  Owing to the failure to incorporate in the record the order from which the appeal is taken, we are not advised as to the grounds upon which the motion was denied . . . . 

Id. at 218-19, 110 S.E.2d at 856.
Although the record on appeal in the instant case contains the full transcript of the hearing before the trial court, including the Departmentâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction argument and the trial courtâ€™s oral ruling on the issue, the Department failed to include the trial courtâ€™s final order in the record.Â  As both court rule and this Courtâ€™s precedent provide, a judgment is effective only when reduced to writing and entered into the record.Â  Rule 58(a)(2), SCRCP;Â  see also Case v. Case, 243 S.C. 447, 451, 134 S.E.2d 394, 396 (1964) (providing that an oral decision â€œis not a final ruling on the merits nor is it binding on the parties until it has been reduced to writing, signed by the Judge [sic] and delivered for recordation.â€).Â  Because the Department failed to include the trial courtâ€™s final order in the record on appeal, the court of appeals properly decided the case without reaching the merits.
To support its argument for reversal, the Department alleges that the Court has an independent obligation to determine the existence of subject matter jurisdiction and that the lower court erred in dismissing the appeal on procedural grounds â€œwithout recognizing the potential impact of the [trial courtâ€™s] decision on South Carolinaâ€™s unified judicial system.â€Â  We disagree.
This argument vastly overstates the case.Â  Primarily, the Department misinterprets an appellate courtâ€™s obligation regarding subject matter jurisdiction.Â  As this Courtâ€™s precedent expressly provides, lack of subject matter jurisdiction in a case may not be waived and ought to be taken notice of by an appellate court.Â  Amisub of S.C., Inc. v. Passmore, 316 S.C. 112, 114, 447 S.E.2d 207, 208 (1994) (citing Anderson v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 382 S.E.2d 897 (1989)).Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals was only required to address the issue of subject matter jurisdiction if it appeared that the lower court did not possess subject matter jurisdiction.
As we have instructed, subject matter jurisdiction refers to a courtâ€™s constitutional or statutory power to adjudicate a case.Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 100, 610 S.E.2d 494, 498 (2005).Â  Stated somewhat differently, â€œsubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Id. (citing Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 526 S.E.2d 222 (2000)).
Article V, Â§ 11 of the South Carolina Constitution provides that â€œ[t]he Circuit Court shall be a general trial court with original jurisdiction in civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive jurisdiction shall be given to inferior courts, and shall have such appellate jurisdiction as provided by law.â€Â  Dealing specifically with the issue of probation, the South Carolina Code provides that â€œthe judge of a court of record with criminal jurisdiction at the time of sentence may suspend the imposition . . . of a sentence and place the defendant on probation . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-410 (Supp. 2005).
The Department argues that the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to consider Johnsonâ€™s request because the request was not accompanied by a recommendation from the agent in charge of the responsible county probation office in support of early termination.Â  This argument is based upon the language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-23-130 (Supp. 2005), which provides that â€œ[u]pon the satisfactory fulfillment of the conditions of probation, the court, with the recommendation of the agent in charge of the responsible county probation office, may terminate the probationer or supervised prisoner from supervision.â€
Modern notions of subject matter jurisdiction, illustrated by this Courtâ€™s opinion in Gentry, resoundingly reject the Departmentâ€™s position.Â  Clearly, the circuit courtâ€™s power and authority to hear cases involving probation derives from Article V, Â§ 11 of the South Carolina Constitution and Â§ 24-21-410 of the Code.Â  Accordingly, a recommendation from the probation office has no relevance to the circuit courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction to hear cases involving the early termination of probation.
To support its subject matter jurisdiction argument, the Department relies on several cases dealing with the issue of probation revocation.Â  Specifically, these cases hold that a court does not have subject matter jurisdiction to revoke probation or hear a matter involving a probation violation absent the issuance of an arrest warrant from a probation officer.Â  See e.g. State v. Felder, 313 S.C. 55, 56, 437 S.E.2d 42, 43 (1993) (â€œIf a warrant has not been issued, the trial court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to revoke probation . . . .â€); and Gray v. State, 276 S.C. 634, 636, 281 S.E.2d 226, 226 (1981) (â€œFailure to comply with the warrant procedures . . . deprives the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction to revoke probation.â€).
At the outset, this argument is unpersuasive due to the distinctions between the statutes at issue.Â  Section 24-21-300 provides â€œ[t]he issuance of a citation or warrant . . . gives jurisdiction to the court . . . at any hearing on the violation.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Similarly, Â§ 24-21-450 provides that a warrant must be issued before a probationer may be detained so that he may then be brought before a judge.Â  In contrast, Â§ 24-23-130 does not contain the word â€œjurisdiction,â€ nor is the statute characterized by such process-oriented language as is found in Â§ 24-21-450.[2]
Furthermore, the phrasing of the statute belies the interpretation the Department offers.Â  Specifically, Â§ 24-23-130 suggests that the recommendation of the probation officer is only necessary at some stage before a personâ€™s probation may be terminated early.Â  Accordingly, the plainest reading of the statue does not support the proposition that a court only has the power to hear early termination of probation cases after a probation officer has made a favorable recommendation.Â  Instead, the statute contemplates that the trial court (1) has the discretion to call an early termination of probation case, on either the Departmentâ€™s or the probationerâ€™s motion, (2) has the power to decide whether it shall conduct a hearing (which is required to include the probation officerâ€™s recommendation), and (3) has full discretion in ultimately rendering a decision.Â  Instructively, this is the precise scenario that occurred in the instant case.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
 MOORE, WALLER, and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

[1] At the hearing, a Department witness testified that the Department was opposed to early termination of Johnsonâ€™s probation.
[2] Because this case does not involve probation revocation, we express no opinion as to the effect this Courtâ€™s holdings in Gentry and Dove v. Gold Kist, 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994) may have on the continued validity of prior pronouncements that an arrest warrant affects a courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction.
