title: State v. Bryant
description: This is an appeal from a capital sentencing proceeding in which the trial court sentenced James Nathaniel Bryant to death.  Bryant appeals claiming that the trial court erred in 1) failing to require that jurors be physically present during jury selection; 2) failing to order the State to produce Bryantâ€™s prison records pursuant to Brady v. Maryland and Rule 5, SCRCrimP; and 3) failing to admit the defense expertâ€™s opinion testimony that the death penalty was more merciful than a sentence of life without parole.  The Court affirms.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
James Nathaniel Bryant, III, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26278
Heard January 3, 2007 - Filed February 27, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek and Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, both of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia, and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  This is an appeal from a capital sentencing proceeding in which the trial court sentenced James Nathaniel Bryant, III (â€œBryantâ€) to death.Â  Bryant appeals claiming that the trial court erred in 1) failing to require that jurors be physically present during jury selection; 2) failing to order the State to produce Bryantâ€™s prison records pursuant to Brady v. Maryland and Rule 5, SCRCrimP; and 3) failing to admit the defense expertâ€™s opinion testimony that the death penalty was more merciful than a sentence of life without parole.Â  We affirm.
Factual/Procedural Background
In June 2000, Cpl. Dennis Lyden of the Horry County Police Department (â€œCpl. Lydenâ€) was placing Bryant under arrest for driving with a suspended license when Bryant suddenly turned and wrestled Cpl. Lyden to the ground.Â  During the course of the struggle, Bryant managed to obtain Cpl. Lydenâ€™s flashlight and pistol magazine from the officerâ€™s duty belt and used them to severely beat Cpl. Lyden about the head.Â  After beating the officer unconscious, Bryant took Cpl. Lydenâ€™s pistol from his holster and shot him in the head at close range.Â  Bryant drove off, taking the pistol and the pistol magazine with him and leaving Cpl. Lydenâ€™s body where it had fallen.Â  After an extensive manhunt, Horry County law enforcement apprehended Bryant the next day.Â  
A grand jury indicted Bryant for murder and armed robbery.Â  Bryantâ€™s first issue on appeal involves the jury selection and capital voir dire beginning in September 2004.[1] Â During jury selection, the parties individually examined a total of sixty-seven jurors divided into thirteen panels.Â  During individual voir dire, the parties inquired to the court about the method of jury selection.Â  The court replied that jurors would be called for striking in the same order they had been qualified and that jurors would be brought before the parties to view before striking.Â  The trial court eventually qualified forty-three potential jurors for service.Â  
During the selection process, counsel for Bryant requested that the jurors be redrawn before being presented for striking.Â  The trial court agreed to the request, but announced that instead of physically appearing for final jury selection, the parties would note their selections on a paper list of the jurors in the revised order based on their recollections from individual voir dire (â€œpaper strikesâ€).Â  Bryantâ€™s counsel objected to this method of jury selection claiming that because they had counted on physically viewing the jurors, counsel had not taken sufficient notes during voir dire to adequately exercise paper strikes.Â Â  The court assured the defense that they would be given a chance to review their notes, juror sheets, and information forms, and reminded counsel that they had extensively interviewed each juror the week before.Â  When counsel continued to object to paper strikes, the court offered them a chance to withdraw their request to have the jurors redrawn and instead conduct jury selection as originally planned.Â  Counsel for Bryant declined this offer and jury selection proceeded with the jurors being redrawn and the parties exercising paper strikes.
The trial court initially addressed the issue in Bryantâ€™s second claim on appeal in a pre-trial motion to compel.Â  During the motion hearing, Bryant claimed that the State was withholding certain discoverable documents believed by Bryant to be in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Corrections (SCDC).Â  The court determined that the State had largely complied with Bryantâ€™s discovery requests, finding no reason not to believe the State when it claimed that certain documents being requested did not exist.Â  Where the existence of a particular document was unclear, the trial court ordered the State to offer a definitive answer as to whether or not the documents existed.Â  
The issue of document disclosure arose again at the conclusion of the guilt phase of the proceedings.Â  Just prior to the start of the sentencing phase, the court asked if any matters needed to be further addressed.Â  Neither party requested any further hearing at that point.Â  However, during the sentencing phase of the proceedings, the defense requested an in camera hearing on the Stateâ€™s failure to produce the same documents at issue in the pre-guilt phase motion to compel.Â  Reviewing the list of classes of documents Bryant claimed the State had failed to produce, the trial court again found no indication that the State had produced incomplete documents, or failed to produce any documents that in fact existed.Â  The court offered Bryant a chance to make a motion for continuance to which counsel for Bryant responded, â€œno.â€Â  
The next day, just before the defense called their last witness, Bryantâ€™s counsel moved for a continuance based on the Stateâ€™s failure to turn over the same SCDC records at issue in previous in camera discussions.Â  The court denied the motion for a continuance, finding once again that what records existed had been provided, and that even if records the State claimed were non-existent did actually exist, they would not prejudice Bryantâ€™s case.Â  
The trial court addressed the SCDC documents a final time when the defense moved for a new trial â€œbased on the Stateâ€™s noncompliance with the discovery rules and the Courtâ€™s denial of our motion for a continuance.â€Â  The court denied the motion noting that the issue had been dealt with â€œextensivelyâ€ and reiterated its findings made throughout the trial that some of the documents were in the possession of the defense; the alleged contents of other â€œmissingâ€ documents had been stipulated to; and there had been no showing of prejudice due to the absence of the documents.
Bryantâ€™s third claim on appeal involves the testimony of Lorita Whitaker (â€œWhitakerâ€), an expert in clinical social work and human behavior in prison, who testified for the defense during the sentencing phase on the dismal conditions of prison life.Â  When asked on direct if it was her opinion that prison was a pretty miserable place, she answered, â€œSome people feel that the death penalty is more merciful than life without parole.â€ The court sustained the Stateâ€™s prompt objection that the expert was â€œgetting into the ultimate issue.â€Â  
At the conclusion of the sentencing proceeding, the jury recommended Bryant be sentenced to death.Â  This appeal followed and Bryant raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      I.  
       Did the trial court deny Bryantâ€™s constitutional right to a fair trial by an impartial jury by refusing Bryantâ€™s request to have the jurors physically present during jury selection?Â 
        
        
    
    
      II.
       Did the trial court deny Bryant a fair sentencing proceeding by refusing to order the State to produce Bryantâ€™s prison records?
        
        
    
    
      III. 
       Did the trial court err in refusing to allow Bryantâ€™s expert witness to opine that some people feel the death penalty is more merciful than a sentence of life without parole?
    
  

Standard of Review
In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  The conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to the sound discretion of the trial judge, who will not be reversed in the absence of a prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Bridges, 278 S.C. 447, 448, 298 S.E.2d 212, 212 (1982).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Garrett, 350 S.C. 613, 619, 567 S.E.2d 523, 526 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
Law/Analysis 
I.Â  Jury selection
Bryant argues that the trial court erred in refusing to allow the jurors to be physically present during jury selection.Â  Bryant claims the alleged error substantially impaired his ability to exercise peremptory strikes in a meaningful manner and therefore deprived him of his constitutional guarantee of a fair trial by an impartial jury.Â  See U.S. Const. Amend. VI; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 14.Â  We disagree.
Peremptory strikes are not constitutional rights.Â  They are creatures of statute and â€œa means to achieve the end of an impartial jury.â€Â  State v. Potts, 347 S.C. 126, 130, 554 S.E.2d 38, 40 (2001) (quoting Ross v. Oklahoma, 487 U.S. 81, 88 (1988)).Â  Therefore, a defendant seeking to overturn a guilty verdict based on the way in which peremptory challenges were exercised must show that the statute granting him peremptory challenges was violated or that the jury which tried him was not impartial.Â 
Id. at 131, 554 S.E.2d at 40.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1100 (Supp. 2005) provides:

In impaneling juries in criminal cases, the jurors shall be called, sworn and impaneled anew for the trial of each case, according to the established practice.Â  

Bryant argues that the trial court violated the statute granting him peremptory challenges because striking jurors on paper without physically viewing the jurors was not an â€œestablished practiceâ€ of jury selection.Â  
Because a trial court is given enormous discretion in conducting a criminal trial, we may logically conclude that â€œestablished practiceâ€ does not refer to only one method of impaneling a jury.Â  Although not the most common method of jury selection in criminal trials, paper strikes are often used in this jurisdiction and their use has been held to be valid.Â  See Potts, 347 S.C. 126, 554 S.E.2d 38 (upholding the use of paper strikes by a criminal defendant in magistrateâ€™s court who claimed the use of paper strikes violated his right to personally confront potential jurors).Â  Because Â§ 14-7-1100 is a blanket rule applicable in all criminal cases, this Court will not begin injecting judicial exceptions into the statutory scheme by holding that the paper strike method is only an â€œestablished practiceâ€ in non-death penalty cases.Â  
Furthermore, there is no evidence that Bryant did not receive a fair trial by an impartial jury.Â  The record reveals a thorough screening process with over 800 pages of capital voir dire consisting of individual examination of each juror by defense counsel.Â  Additionally, when counsel for Bryant indicated they were unprepared for the paper strike method, the trial court granted the defense more time to review their notes prior to beginning the striking process and promised to give counsel extra time to decide on a strike during the procedure.Â  
Additionally, the record shows that Bryant affirmatively chose to forego the physical viewing of jurors and proceed with the paper strike method as part of a strategic move to generate a strike list more beneficial to the defense.Â  While the parties initially agreed to view jurors by calling them forward in the order they were qualified, counsel for Bryant later requested that the jurors be redrawn.Â  Although the solicitor did not object to a redraw, the trial court noted a disadvantage to the State in granting Bryantâ€™s request.Â  Therefore, the court allowed the jurors to be redrawn, but announced that by proceeding in this manner, the parties would strike the jurors on the paper list instead of viewing the jurors in person.Â  Upon objection by defense counsel to the use of paper strikes, the trial court gave Bryant the opportunity to withdraw his request to have the jurors redrawn and proceed with the original plan to view the jurors in the order they were qualified.Â  Bryantâ€™s counsel refused the trial courtâ€™s offer, indicating to this Court that counsel for Bryant clearly recalled enough about the jurors to know that a redraw would be more beneficial to their strategy than proceeding in the original order.Â  Without more to substantiate a claim of prejudice, Bryant may not now claim that the trial strategy he opted for warrants a new trial.Â 
See State v. Babb, 299 S.C. 451, 455, 385 S.E.2d 827, 829 (1989) (â€œ[A] party cannot complain of an error which his own conduct has induced.â€).
Because the use of paper strikes did not deprive Bryant of a fair trial by an impartial jury, we hold that the trial court did not err in refusing to allow jurors to be present during jury selection.Â  Â 
II.Â  Discovery of Bryantâ€™s SCDC records
Bryant argues that the trial courtâ€™s failure to order the State to turn over SCDC documents after hearing Bryantâ€™s pre-guilt phase motion to compel denied Bryant a fair sentencing proceeding.Â  Bryant also argues that the trial courtâ€™s subsequent denial of a motion for continuance and a motion for a new trial, both based on the Stateâ€™s refusal to turn over the SCDC documents, denied Bryant a fair sentencing proceeding.Â  We disagree.
Under Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963), the State must disclose evidence that is favorable to the accused if the evidence is material to either guilt or punishment.Â  Defendants making a claim under Brady must demonstrate that 1) the evidence was favorable to the defense; 2) it was in the possession of or known to the prosecution; 3) it was suppressed by the prosecution; and 4) it was material to guilt or punishment.Â  Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 524, 514 S.E.2d 320, 324 (1999).Â  Similarly, under Rule 5, SCRCrimP, criminal defendants are entitled to their statements, criminal records, and any documents or tangible objects material to the preparation of their defense or intended for use by the prosecution.
Bryant sent a discovery request to the State requesting that his prison records be handed over as Brady and Rule 5 material.Â  These records included:Â  classification reports, behavioral reports, visitation reports, counseling records, work records, â€œshakedown logs,â€ cell inspection reports, and seminar records.Â  The trial court addressed Bryantâ€™s Brady and Rule 5 requests a total of four times during the trial - in a pre-guilt phase motion; in an in camera hearing during the sentencing phase; in a motion to compel at the close of the defenseâ€™s argument in the sentencing phase; and in a motion for a new trial.Â  Each of the four times Bryant raised the issue of the â€œmissingâ€ classes of documents supposedly accessible to SCDC and the State, the trial judge conducted a thorough examination into the nature of the requested documents, why the documents were necessary to Bryantâ€™s defense, and the Stateâ€™s reasons for not producing the documents.Â  
In the instant case, the trial courtâ€™s findings and conclusions as to each class of documents are clearly supported by the record and function to negate one or more of the elements required to make a claim under Brady.Â  Specifically, the trial court found that 1) the classification reports, behavioral reports, and counseling records had been handed over to Bryant by the State; 2) the absence of visitation reports, work records, cell inspection reports, and shakedown logs did not prejudice the defense - a finding that the defense acknowledged to be true; and 3) the visitation reports, work records, shakedown logs, and cell inspection reports did not exist.Â  Likewise, these findings negate the substantive requirements of Rule 5, SCRCrimP, which requires that the documents requested be â€œmaterialâ€ to the preparation of the defense.Â  
Moreover, Bryantâ€™s acknowledgment to the trial court that the absence of certain documents would not be prejudicial to the defense goes squarely against Bryantâ€™s contention in this appeal.Â  If Bryant conceded that the courtâ€™s ruling was not prejudicial, he may not later assert that ruling denied him a fair trial.Â  See State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 51, 476 S.E.2d 683, 687 (1996) (by proceeding to trial after affirmatively stating â€œthe defense is ready,â€ a defendant waived his right to complain he was given inadequate time to preview discovery materials).
Bryantâ€™s claim is essentially grounded in the last-minute turnover of records by SCDC to Bryantâ€™s counsel the night before the trial.Â  We note that this Court does not condone such behavior, and we emphasize the importance of conscientiously honoring the requirements of Brady and Rule 5, SCRCrimP.[2] Â However, the acquisition of requested documents at the last minute is not uncommon in the practice of law and, in this case, is not grounds for a new trial in light of the trial courtâ€™s findings and the partiesâ€™ stipulations with respect to the various documents.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in ruling on Bryantâ€™s various Brady and Rule 5 motions.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Expert witness testimony
Bryant argues that the trial court erred in refusing to allow Bryantâ€™s expert witness to opine that the death penalty was more merciful than a sentence of life without parole.Â  We disagree.
At trial, Bryant called Lorita Whitaker, an expert in clinical social work and â€œhuman behavior in prisons.â€Â  While testifying on direct examination on the dismal conditions of prison life in general, Whitaker stated that â€œsome people feel that the death penalty is more merciful than life without parole.â€Â  The State immediately objected to Whitakerâ€™s statement and the trial court sustained the objection.Â  Defense counsel immediately proceeded to his final question with no contemporaneous objection to the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Because the issue was not raised to and ruled on by the trial court, the admissibility of Whitakerâ€™s statement is not preserved for appeal.Â 
See State v. Moore, 357 S.C. 458, 593 S.E.2d 608 (2004).Â  
The circumstances of this case are nearly indistinguishable from those in our recent opinion in State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 623 S.E.2d 378 (2006), where although the admissibility of testimony on prison conditions had not been preserved for review, this Court warned:

We take this opportunity . . . to caution the State and the defense that evidence presented in a penalty phase of a capital trial is to be restricted to the individual defendant and the individual defendantâ€™s actions, behavior, and character.Â  Generally, questions involving escape and prison conditions are not relevant to the question of whether a defendant should be sentenced to death or life imprisonment without parole.Â  We emphasize that how inmates, other than the defendant at trial, are treated in prison . . . is inappropriate evidence in the penalty phase of a capital trial.Â  We admonish both the State and the defense that the penalty phase should focus solely on the defendant and any evidence introduced in the penalty phase should be connected to that particular defendant.Â  

Id. at 498-499, 623 S.E.2d at 385.Â  We reiterate this admonishment in our opinion today and remain firm in our view that testimony seeking to portray life imprisonment as preferable to capital punishment is improper, particularly where, as here, the expertâ€™s testimony did not focus specifically on the defendant, but on prison conditions generally.Â  
Proportionality Review
As required, we conduct a proportionality review of Bryantâ€™s death sentence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C) (2003).Â  The United States Constitution prohibits the imposition of the death penalty when it is either excessive or disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 590, 300 S.E.2d 63, 74 (1982).Â  In conducting a proportionality review, we search for similar cases in which the death sentence has been upheld.Â  Id.; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(E) (2003).
After reviewing the entire record, we conclude that the sentence in this case was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.Â  Furthermore, a review of similar cases illustrates that imposing the death sentence in this case would be neither excessive nor disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  See State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500  (1999) (holding that the death penalty was warranted where defendant killed a police officer performing a routine traffic stop); State v.
Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 545 S.E.2d 805 (1999) (holding that death penalty was proper where defendant killed the driver of armored van during armed robbery of the vehicle); and State v. Johnson, 306 S.C. 119; 410 S.E.2d 547 (1991) (holding that the death penalty was proper where the defendant shot a state trooper six times after being stopped for erratic driving).
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm Bryantâ€™s conviction and death sentence in accordance with the trial courtâ€™s decision.
MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justices James W. Johnson, Jr., and L. Casey Manning, concur.

[1] The 2004 jury selection was for Bryantâ€™s second trial on these charges.Â  This Court reversed Bryantâ€™s 2001 conviction and death sentence in State v. Bryant, 354 S.C. 390, 581 S.E.2d 157 (2003), on the basis that law enforcementâ€™s contact with jurorsâ€™ family members compromised Bryantâ€™s right to a fair and impartial jury.
[2] Specifically, we are concerned that the solicitor had to resort to subpoenaing SCDC in September 2004 in order to obtain records requested from SCDC pursuant to Bryantâ€™s Brady and Rule 5 motions filed in June 2004.Â  Furthermore, because SCDC did not promptly and fully comply with the solicitorâ€™s subpoenas, the solicitor had to make repeated phone calls and visits to SCDC in order to acquire the requested records.Â  The situation ultimately required a court order directing SCDC to immediately provide the parties with affirmative responses as to the whereabouts and/or existence of certain records requested by Bryant.Â  The record provides no reason for SCDCâ€™s delayed handling of the matter and we issue this reminder that state agencies are no different from the solicitor in their obligations to comply with the requirements of Brady and Rule 5.Â

title: In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Larry Gene Beaver
description: This case involves the issue of whether the circuit court erred by dismissing the State's Sexually Violent Predator petition.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Larry Gene Beaver,
Respondent,
v.
The State of South Carolina, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26279
Heard January 3, 2007 - Filed February 27, 2007Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, and Assistant Attorney General David M. Stumbo, all of Columbia, for appellant.
William Isaac Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent pled guilty to one count of lewd act on a minor.Â  He was sentenced to seven years imprisonment, suspended on nine months confinement and three years probation.Â  The State commenced a civil action seeking respondentâ€™s commitment as a sexually violent predator pursuant to the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator Act (the SVP Act), S.C. Code Â§ 44-48-10 through -170 (Supp. 2006).Â  At the probable cause hearing, the judge found no probable cause to believe respondent is a sexually violent predator and dismissed the action.Â  We certified this case from the Court of Appeals.
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err by dismissing the Stateâ€™s Sexually Violent Predator petition?

FACTS
In 1993, respondent was charged in Tennessee with four counts of aggravated rape of a child, two counts of aggravated sexual battery, and two counts of incest.Â  The charges were based on the molestation of his ten-year-old and eight-year-old daughters, whom he had forced to perform multiple sex acts with him.Â  Respondent pled guilty to one count of aggravated sexual battery and one count of incest.Â  He was sentenced to eight years imprisonment on the sexual battery charge and six years imprisonment, to be served concurrently, on the incest charge.
In 2003, respondent was residing in South Carolina and was giving piano lessons in his home.Â  The mother of one of his piano students discovered numerous letters and e-mails respondent had written to her daughter, who was ten-years-old, between April and June 2003.Â  When the mother questioned the victim, she reported that between December 2002 and June 2003, respondent had hugged and kissed her, and, on one occasion, he ran his tongue over her lips.Â  The victim also stated respondent put his hand under her shirt and rubbed her chest area with his hands one day when she felt sick.
Respondent was indicted on one count of lewd act on a child under the age of sixteen and one count of communicating obscene messages.Â  In September 2004, he pled guilty to the lewd act charge.
Prior to respondentâ€™s release from prison, his case was referred to the Multi-Disciplinary Team, which assesses whether a prisoner should possibly be termed a â€œsexually violent predator.â€Â  His case was referred because his conviction of lewd act on a minor is a qualifying offense under the SVP Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(2)(k) (Supp. 2006).Â  The Multi-Disciplinary Team reviewed his case and determined there was probable cause to believe he is a sexually violent predator as defined by the SVP Act.Â  The Prosecutorâ€™s Review Committee also determined there was probable cause to believe respondent meets the statutory criteria for civil commitment as a sexually violent predator.
The State then filed a petition seeking respondentâ€™s civil commitment to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health for long-term control, care, and treatment as a sexually violent predator.Â  Judge John L. Breeden found the Stateâ€™s petition set forth sufficient facts to establish probable cause to believe respondent meets the statutory criteria for commitment.[1]Â  The case was then called for a probable cause hearing before Judge Edward B. Cottingham.[2]
At the hearing, the judge expressed his concern about applying the SVP Act to respondent because respondent â€œpled to fondling, non-violent [and] now they want to keep him in jail for something that they didnâ€™t indict him for.â€[3]Â  The judge stated he was concerned that respondent pled specifically to a non-violent fondling charge, apparently entered an Alford[4] plea[5] to that charge, and received only nine months of active time.Â  The judge stated it would be appropriate to use the SVP Act if respondent had raped or ravished someone or had intercourse with a young child; however, he did not think the SVP Act was intended for someone who pleads to a non-violent fondling charge.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge stated, â€œI canâ€™t order this but with his prior record, I would suggest that he quit teaching young children.â€
In his order, the judge found the State had failed to demonstrate that probable cause exists to find respondent to be a sexually violent predator and that the State had failed to provide sufficient evidence that respondent suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes him likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility as required by the SVP Act.
DISCUSSION
The lower court was asked to determine whether there was probable cause to believe respondent is a sexually violent predator.Â  A sexually violent predator is defined in the SVP Act as:Â  

. . . a person who (a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense; and (b) suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(1) (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œSexually violent offenseâ€ includes committing a lewd act upon a child under sixteen.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(2)(k) (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œMental abnormalityâ€ means a mental condition affecting a personâ€™s emotional or volitional capacity that predisposes the person to commit sexually violent offenses.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(3) (Supp. 2006).Â  Finally, â€œlikely to engage in acts of sexual violenceâ€ means the personâ€™s propensity to commit acts of sexual violence is of such a degree as to pose a menace to the health and safety of others.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(9) (Supp. 2006).
We find the lower court erred by finding no probable cause to believe respondent meets the definition in the SVP Act.Â  Respondent meets part (a) of the definition because he has been convicted of a sexually violent offense, i.e. lewd act upon a child under sixteen.Â  The lower court erred by finding the lewd act charge was â€œnon-violent.â€Â  The lower court determined that respondent should not be confined as a sexually violent predator on the basis of a â€œnon-violentâ€ charge.Â  It is true that the lewd act charge is considered non-violent for criminal purposes.[6]Â  However, the Legislature has deemed it appropriate to consider that charge violent for the purposes of the SVP Act. Â Section 44-48-30(2)(k) includes committing or attempting a lewd act upon a child under sixteen as a sexually violent offense that qualifies a person to be considered a sexually violent predator.Â  Accordingly, the lower court erred by referring to the lewd act charge as a non-violent charge in this civil probable cause hearing.
Further, the lower court erred by finding the State had failed to provide sufficient evidence that respondent suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder as required under part (b) of the definition.Â  At the probable cause hearing, the State introduced evidence that respondent suffers from pedophilia.Â  The State also presented sufficient evidence to show that there is probable cause to believe respondent is â€œlikely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.â€Â  This evidence consisted of respondentâ€™s guilty pleas to aggravated sexual battery and incest arising out of the molestation of one of his natural daughters.Â  A few years after respondentâ€™s release from prison, he performed a lewd act upon a ten-year-old girl.Â  While the first incident involved his own child, the next incident involved a young girl whom he had known only for a short time.Â  His behavior reveals a propensity to commit acts of sexual violence to such a degree as to pose a menace to the health and safety of young girls. 
Pursuant to the SVP Act, and particularly S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(D) (Supp. 2006), the State is not able to require a mental examination of the offender until a judge, after a hearing, has found that there is probable cause to believe the offender is a sexually violent predator.Â  Therefore, the State is generally unable to produce any mental health information at the probable cause hearing because probable cause must first be found by a judge at the hearing before such evidence can be obtained. Â The Stateâ€™s inability to provide mental health evidence does not prevent a finding of probable cause.Â  Accordingly, the lower court erred by finding the State had failed to provide sufficient evidence that respondent suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes him likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined.Â  Cf. In re Treatment and Care of Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 568 S.E.2d 338 (2002) (on review, the appellate court will not disturb the hearing courtâ€™s finding on probable cause unless found to be without evidence that reasonably supports the hearing courtâ€™s finding). 
As an additional sustaining ground, respondent argues the Stateâ€™s petition should be dismissed because it cannot comply with the statutory requirement that the court must conduct a trial to determine whether the person is a sexually violent predator within sixty days of the completion of the probable cause hearing.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90 (Supp. 2006) (â€œWithin sixty days after the completion of a [probable cause] hearing, the court must conduct a trial to determine whether the person is a sexually violent predatory.â€).Â  However, because probable cause was not found at the conclusion of the hearing, the time period set out in Â§ 44-48-90 is inapplicable.Â  Therefore, there is no merit to respondentâ€™s additional sustaining ground.
CONCLUSION
Because there is no evidence to support the lower courtâ€™s finding on probable cause, we reverse and remand to the circuit court.Â  On remand, the circuit court shall direct that respondent be transferred to an appropriate secure facility for evaluation as to whether he is a sexually violent predator.Â  Further, on remand, the circuit court shall approve a qualified expert to conduct the evaluation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(D) (Supp. 2006).
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, J., and Acting Justices James W. Johnson, Jr., and L. Casey Manning, concur.

Â§ 44-48-80(A) (Supp. 2006) (â€œUpon filing of a petition [for a probable cause determination,] the court must determine whether probable cause exists to believe that the person named in the petition is a sexually violent predator.Â  If the court determines that probable cause exists to believe that the person is a sexually violent predator, the person must be taken into custody if he is not already confined in a secure facility.â€).
[2]See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B) (Supp. 2006) (after the initial determination of probable cause by the court, â€œthe person must be provided with notice of the opportunity to appear in person at a hearing to contest probable cause as to whether the detained person is a sexually violent predator.â€).Â  If the probable cause determination is made at the hearing, then the court must direct that the person be transferred to an appropriate secure facility for an evaluation as to whether the person is a sexually violent predator.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(D) (Supp. 2006).Â  After the evaluation, a trial is held to determine whether the person is a sexually violent predator.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90 (Supp. 2006).Â  Therefore, a finding of probable cause at the probable cause hearing does not automatically place the person in confinement and finally decide the question of whether that person is a sexually violent predator.
[3]The judge stated he was concerned that a judge can incarcerate someone and say, â€œâ€˜This is your sentence.â€™Â  And then they complete the sentence, and you say, â€˜Wait a minute.Â  We [sic] going to keep you a while longer.â€™â€Â  The judge further commented, â€œThe State had a chance to put him away forever if they chose to, and for reasons good and sufficient for them . . . they did not.Â  So, Iâ€™m not going to let you incarcerate him any further on this charge.â€Â  The judgeâ€™s comments on this point are in error.Â  See, e.g., In re Care and Treatment of Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 550 S.E.2d 311 (2001), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 1062 (2002) (purpose of the SVP Act is civil commitment, which does not implicate retribution).
[4]North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).
[5]There is no evidence in the record as to whether the lewd act plea was actually an Alford plea.
[6]See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-140 (2003) (it is unlawful to willfully and lewdly commit or attempt a lewd or lascivious act upon or with the body, or its parts, of a child under the age of sixteen years, with the intent of arousing, appealing to, or gratifying the lust or passions or sexual desires of the child); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2006) (crime of lewd act not included in listing of offenses deemed violent).
